text: 'Some time ago, a website talked about the dangers of public check-ins – telling everyone online where you are. The website's message was clear: you might think you are just saying, ‘Hey, I’m at this place,’ but you are also telling everyone, including people you might not want to meet. This made people more aware that sharing everything online might have problems. The internet gives us many chances to share our lives with a global audience, offering possibilities like wealth and fame. So, we dive into the internet, sharing personal stories and photos. But soon, we realize it can be dangerous and confusing. Is this sad? Maybe, but don't lose hope. There is a guide for this future, created by early internet users. In the early days of the web, they explored and found all the dangers. They lost jobs, made and lost friends, and dealt with fame before social media existed. These early users, the first bloggers, have already experienced what many of us are going through now. Before we forget their stories, we should learn from them. If we don't learn from history, we might repeat it. In January 1994, Justin Hall, a 19-year-old student, started posting on the ‘WWW’, which was mostly used by students and scientists. The web was created at Cern, a physics lab in Switzerland, to help researchers share their work. Hall saw it as a chance to share his life. He created a detailed online autobiography with words, photos, and art. In January 1996, he started a daily blog, and many people came to see a young man exploring this new medium. Hall shared everything: if you met him, you might appear on his site; no topic was off-limits. It was the work of someone who liked attention, but it was also artistic. One day, visitors to Hall’s site found it gone, replaced by a video called Dark Night. He shared that he had fallen in love, but when he wrote about it online, he was told, ‘either the blog goes, or I do’. He realized that sharing his life online made people not trust him. He stopped the blog, but the problem remains. Sharing online is fun, but if you think it will make people like you, you might be disappointed. In 2002, Heather Armstrong, a web worker in Los Angeles, had a blog called Dooce. She sometimes wrote about her job at a software company. One day, a colleague sent her blog to all the vice presidents at her company, including some she had made fun of, and she lost her job. Experts call this the ‘online distribution effect’: the feeling that we can say things online that we wouldn’t say in person. But the web is not a place where we can say anything without consequences. Our online lives are connected to our real lives. If we forget this, we might make big mistakes. Armstrong’s story ended well. She was upset and stopped blogging for a while, but she got married and started her blog again, focusing on her family. Now, she is a successful ‘mommy blogger’ and her writing supports her family. She learned that just because we can say anything online, it doesn’t mean we should.'

Some time ago, scientists started a campaign to warn people about a low-budget film called "What the Bleep Do We Know?" This film used a mix of documentary and drama to show that there is a lot about our universe we don't understand. Most scientists agree that we don't know everything about the universe. However, some scientists felt the need to warn the public about the film, calling it "atrocious" and "a very dangerous piece of work." This made the film seem interesting to watch.
At first, the film seemed harmless. Scientists talked about how new discoveries show the universe is stranger than we thought. But then the film talked about discoveries like water molecules being affected by thoughts. It showed pictures of ice crystals looking nice after being talked to by someone happy, and not nice after being exposed to someone in a bad mood. Some people find this evidence convincing, but many scientists do not. They want more proof that thoughts can affect water.
The real problem is that the film's claims were not strange enough. Scientists have found that the universe is made of unknown matter and is expanding because of a mysterious force called "dark energy." These discoveries are based on years of research. Other amazing discoveries include how our brains process events and the origins of modern humans. Some scientists even think there are links between life on Earth and the design of the universe.
Science is not finished. We are still far from knowing everything. Concepts like chaos and quantum uncertainty show that there are limits to what we can know. Some physicists are trying to create a "Theory of Everything" to explain all the forces and particles in the universe. Despite these efforts, many people think the universe is best described in one word: incredible.

'For me, writing novels is a challenge, but writing short stories is a joy. If writing novels is like planting a forest, then writing short stories is like planting a garden. Both are important and create a complete picture that I love. The trees in the forest give shade, and the wind moves the leaves, which sometimes turn gold. In the garden, flowers bloom, and their colors attract bees and butterflies, showing the change of seasons. Since I started writing, I have switched between writing novels and short stories. After finishing a novel, I want to write short stories. After finishing short stories, I want to write a novel. I never mix the two. Writing novels and short stories might use different parts of the brain, and it takes time to switch between them. I started my career with two short novels in 1975, and from 1984 to 1985, I began writing short stories. I didn't know much about writing short stories then, so it was hard, but I found it memorable. My fictional world grew, and readers liked this new side of me. One of my first works, ‘Breaking Waves’, was in my first short-story collection, Tales from Abroad. This was my start as a short-story writer. One joy of short stories is they don’t take long to finish. It usually takes me about a week to make a short story decent (though I revise a lot). It’s not like the long time it takes to write a novel. You go into a room, finish your work, and leave. That’s it. Writing a novel can feel like it takes forever, and I sometimes wonder if I’ll finish. So, writing short stories is a nice change. Another good thing about short stories is you can create them from small ideas, a word, or an image. It’s like jazz improvisation, with the story leading me. Also, with short stories, you don’t have to worry about failing. If the idea doesn’t work, you just move on. Even great writers like F. Scott Fitzgerald and Raymond Carver didn’t always write masterpieces. This comforts me. You can learn from your mistakes and use that in the next story. When I write novels, I try to learn from my short stories. Short stories are like a test for me as a novelist. It’s hard to experiment in a novel, so without short stories, writing novels would be even harder. My short stories are like soft shadows I have left in the world, small footprints I remember. They are like guideposts to my heart, and I am happy to share these feelings with my readers.'

Science can be very abstract, like philosophy, or very practical, like curing diseases. It has made our lives easier but also brought dangers. Science tries to understand small things like ants and atoms, and big things like the universe. It influences poets, politicians, and philosophers. Its beauty is often seen only by experts, and its dangers are often misunderstood. People sometimes think science is more or less important than it really is. Scientists often change or challenge old ideas, and new ideas can be mocked before they become accepted. Science is full of conflict and change. Scientists often disagree, and new discoveries can change our beliefs. For example, in the 17th century, people thought the universe was like a big clock. Later, scientists like Newton and Einstein changed these ideas. Science keeps changing, and with each change, we understand nature better. In the past, scientists thought they knew everything, but then they discovered many new things like radioactivity and black holes. Today, some people think we are close to understanding everything about the universe. Science is not just for fun; it affects our lives and the world. We have become more than just observers of nature; we can control it a little. But sometimes, we change nature in ways we don't understand. It's important for everyone, not just scientists, to understand science because it affects our future and the world our children will live in. Science helps us plan for the future, and these plans can affect things like government budgets and health.

'Around 2015, after years of growth, big publishers said that ebook sales had stopped growing or even dropped. This made people question the future of ebooks in publishing. One publishing executive said that the excitement about ebooks might have led to bad investments, and his company lost faith in 'the power of the word on the page'. Even though digital and print books can exist together, people still ask if ebooks will 'kill' print books. Whether predicting or dismissing this, the idea of books disappearing makes us think and debate. Why is this idea so strong? Why do we see ebooks and print books as fighting, even if evidence says otherwise? These questions show our mixed feelings about new things and change. In my research, I found that people often think one new technology will replace another. Before digital tech, people thought new inventions would end old media. When TV was invented, some said radio would die, but radio survived by finding new uses, like in cars. The idea of books disappearing isn't new. In 1894, people thought the phonograph would replace books with what we now call audiobooks. This has happened many times. Movies, radio, TV, and smartphones have all been seen as threats to print books. Some said losing books would harm culture, while others praised ebooks too much. The idea of books dying comes up during tech changes because it shows our hopes and fears about change. We form emotional bonds with media as they become part of our lives. Studies show we connect with things like books and computers, even naming our cars or getting mad at our laptops. New tech, like e-readers, means economic and social change and makes us change our bond with familiar things. As tech changes, we miss what we used to have. This is why industries grow around old products. When the printing press spread in 15th-century Europe, people wanted original manuscripts. The move from silent to sound movies in the 1920s made people nostalgic for silent films. The same happened with analog to digital photography and vinyl records to CDs. E-readers made people appreciate 'old' books and their smell. This should comfort those worried about print books disappearing. But the idea of disappearing media will keep being a story about tech's power and our fear of change. We use familiar stories, like tragedy and endings, to understand change. The story of the book's death shows our excitement for the future and fear of losing parts of our world and ourselves.'

'Almost every weekday morning for a year and a half, I woke up at 5:30, brushed my teeth, made coffee, and sat down to write. I wrote about how some of the greatest minds of the past 400 years found time each day to do their best work. I looked at how they organized their schedules to be creative and productive. By writing about the simple details of their daily lives – when they slept, ate, worked, and worried – I wanted to show a new side of their personalities and careers. I wanted to show them as people with habits, just like us. The French gastronome Jean Anthelme Brillat-Savarin once said, ‘Tell me what you eat, and I shall tell you what you are.’ I say, ‘Tell me what time you eat, and if you take a nap afterward.’ In this way, my book is about the circumstances of creative work, not the work itself. It’s about how things are made, not what they mean. But it’s also personal. The novelist John Cheever thought you couldn’t even type a business letter without showing something of your inner self. My book looks at questions I struggle with in my own life: How do you do meaningful creative work while also earning a living? Is it better to focus completely on a project or to work on it a little each day? When there isn’t enough time for everything, do you have to give things up, or can you learn to do more in less time? I don’t pretend to answer these questions in my book – maybe some of them can’t be answered, or can only be solved individually. But I have tried to show examples of how different successful people have faced these challenges. I wanted to show how big creative ideas can be broken down into small daily actions; how your working habits affect your work, and vice versa. The book’s title is Daily Rituals, but it’s really about people’s routines. A routine can seem ordinary and automatic. But a good routine can help you use your time, willpower, and optimism well. A solid routine helps you focus your mental energy and avoid being controlled by your moods. The psychologist William James thought you should put part of your life on autopilot; by forming good habits, he said, we can ‘free our minds to advance to really interesting fields of action.’ Ironically, James himself was a procrastinator and couldn’t stick to a regular schedule. Interestingly, it was a moment of procrastination that led to this book. One Sunday afternoon, I was alone in the office of the small architecture magazine where I worked, trying to write a story due the next day. Instead of working, I was tidying my desk, making coffee, and wasting time. I’m a ‘morning person’, able to focus in the early hours but not much use after lunch. That afternoon, to feel better about this, I started searching online for information about other writers’ working schedules. These were easy to find and very interesting. I thought someone should collect these stories in one place – so I started the Daily Routines blog that afternoon and, now, this book. The blog was casual; I just posted descriptions of people’s routines as I found them in biographies, magazine profiles, newspaper obituaries, and more. For the book, I’ve gathered a much larger and better-researched collection, while keeping the short and varied voices that made the blog appealing. As much as possible, I’ve let my subjects speak for themselves, using quotes from letters, diaries, and interviews. In other cases, I have summarized their routines from other sources. I should mention that this book wouldn’t have been possible without the research of many biographers, journalists, and scholars whose work I used. I have listed all my sources in the Notes section, which I hope will also guide further reading.'

Howard became a palaeontologist because of a change in interest rates when he was six years old. His father, who was careful with money, had a big mortgage and was worried about the economy. He said they could not go on holiday to Spain as planned. Instead, they rented a chalet on the English coast. One day, Howard found an ammonite* on the beach. From then on, he knew he wanted to be a palaeontologist. By the end of university, he knew what kind of palaeontologist he wanted to be. He was interested in the very early times, not in dinosaurs or the Jurassic period. He studied small creatures in grey rocks. When he finished his doctoral thesis, he worried about getting a job. He knew he was good, but he also knew that deserving people do not always get what they want. When a job at Tavistock College in London was available, he applied, but he did not expect much. On the day of his interview, the professor who was supposed to help another candidate had an argument with his wife, crashed his car, and went to the hospital. The interview happened without him, and another professor, who did not like the first professor, made sure Howard got the job. Howard was surprised but happy. Later, he learned the truth but was not too upset. He was glad to have the job and do the work he loved. He often thought about how his work was organized, but life was unpredictable. One day, his briefcase with lecture notes was stolen at an Underground station. Angry, he went back to the college, called to postpone the lecture, and reported the theft. Then he had coffee with a colleague and a visitor from the Natural History Museum in Nairobi. He learned about a new collection of fossils there, which would be his biggest challenge and secure his career. If not for the theft, he would not have known about it. He quickly changed his plans. He decided not to go to a conference in Stockholm or take students to Scotland. Instead, he would find a way to visit the museum in Nairobi. 
*An ammonite is a type of fossil.

Charles Spence will eat almost anything. "We have ice cream made from bee larvae at home," says the Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University in the UK. These larvae might look like maggots, but they have a "slightly nutty, floral" taste. Making bug-eating acceptable is just one of the challenges Spence and his team are working on. Spence studies how our senses work together to create our perception of flavor. His research influences what we eat and drink, from big food companies to top restaurants. Spence and his colleagues study how we experience food and drink, a field known as gastrophysics. They look at who we eat with, how food is arranged, the color and texture of plates, and background noise—all of which affect taste. Spence's book, "The Perfect Meal," written with Betina Piqueras-Fiszman, is full of interesting insights. Did you know that the first person to order in a restaurant enjoys their food the most? Or that we eat about 35% more when dining with one other person, and 75% more with three others? Spence's lab in Oxford is simple and low-tech. By keeping costs low, he can work creatively with chefs who can't afford academic research. Much of his work is funded by a major food company. In the past, research funded by industry was seen as less serious, but now it's considered important because it shows real-world impact. Spence is helping famous brands reduce salt and sugar, often without customers noticing. Research shows that if you tell people about these changes, they focus on the taste and might not like it as much. Spence first met Heston Blumenthal, a famous experimental chef, while working on a project for a big food producer. Together, they created the "Sound of the Sea" dish at Blumenthal's restaurant. Spence's research shows that higher-pitched music makes food taste sweeter, while lower-pitched sounds make it taste bitter. An airline will soon match music with food served to passengers. Last year, a brand released a smartphone app that played music while your ice cream softened, but they didn't match the music to the taste. At home, Spence has had dinner parties with unusual themes, like eating rabbit with fur-wrapped cutlery or using colored lights. For Spence, home, shops, and food events are all extensions of his lab.

Our brains are busier than ever. We get a lot of information, some true and some not, and we have to decide what is important. We also do more things ourselves now. For example, we book our own flights and find things in shops without help. We try to manage our lives, families, jobs, hobbies, and TV shows, often with the help of our smartphones. But there is a problem. We think we are multitasking, doing many things at once, but this is not true. Earl Miller, a neuroscientist at MIT, says our brains are not good at multitasking. We actually switch quickly from one task to another, which makes us less efficient. Multitasking increases stress hormones, which can make us feel confused. It also makes our brains crave new things, distracting us easily. Glenn Wilson, a psychologist, found that trying to focus on a task while having an unread email can lower your IQ by almost 10 points. Multitasking can be worse than being tired. Russ Poldrack, a neuroscientist at Stanford, found that learning while multitasking sends information to the wrong part of the brain. For example, if students do homework and watch TV, the information goes to a part of the brain for skills, not facts. Multitasking also involves making many decisions, which can tire our brains and lead to bad choices. Many people, including business leaders and scientists, find email overwhelming. It is not the email itself, but the large amount of communication. One neuroscientist's son said his father just answers emails all day, which is not far from the truth. We feel we must reply to emails, but it is hard to do that and finish other tasks.

'In a Swedish zoo, a chimpanzee named Santino spent his nights breaking concrete into pieces to throw at visitors during the day. Was he being mean? In caves in the US, female bats help other fruit bat mothers if they can’t find the right position to give birth. Are they being kind? Fifty years ago, these questions would not have been important. Animals had behaviors, and science recorded the results. The idea that animals have feelings and moral systems was seen as sentimental. But recently, this has started to change. Research into the behavior of bats, chimps, rats, dolphins, and chickens has begun to explore animal emotions. This change has reached popular science books, like Mark Bekoff’s Wild Justice and Victoria Braithwaite’s Do Fish Feel Pain?. It has started a debate: can animals be said to have consciousness? This leads to another question: do animals have a sense of right and wrong? In a recent experiment with cows, those that opened a locked gate to get food showed more pleasure than those that had the gate opened for them. If cows enjoy problem-solving, what does it mean for eating beef? The observations are clear, but their meaning is debated. Dr. Jonathan Balcombe, author of Second Nature, believes the only response is to stop eating meat. He thinks humanity is on the verge of a big change in ethics. Aubrey Manning, Professor Emeritus at Edinburgh University, says we should rethink our view of animal thinking. He believes animals have a simpler theory of mind than humans. Professor Euan MacPhail thinks we should stop giving animals human traits. The issue is not just scientific or moral, but philosophical. Can we ever know what it is like to be a bat? Balcombe describes an experiment that seems to show starlings, a type of bird, can get depressed. At Newcastle University, starlings were split into two groups. Half were in nice cages with space and water, and the other half were in small, empty cages. Both groups learned to eat tasty worms from one box and avoid unpleasant worms from another. Later, when only unpleasant worms were offered, only the birds in nice cages ate them. Balcombe concluded that being in a bad cage made the starlings pessimistic. Balcombe, who works with animal rights groups, has a clear bias. He says, ‘We look back with horror on times of racism. Our view about animals will someday be the same. We can’t support animal rights while eating a cheeseburger.’ If he were the only one with this view, it might be easy to dismiss him. But Professor Aubrey Manning agrees. Manning has written a textbook, An Introduction to Animal Behaviour. He says, ‘We are seeing a change. In the early 20th century, people thought animals thought like us, and there was a reaction against that. Now we are going the other way. But it is a difficult subject, and you want to avoid the sound of academics with strong personal opinions.’'

'Critical thinking is a way of understanding what we read or listen to more deeply. Adrian West, from the Edward de Bono Foundation U.K., says that argument can help find the truth. Technology helps us store and process information, but it might also change how we solve problems and make it harder to think deeply. West notes that we are exposed to a lot of poor thinking and opinions, which can overwhelm our ability to reason. More data and information do not always lead to better knowledge or decisions. According to the National Endowment for the Arts, reading literature has decreased by 10%, and this decline is speeding up. Patricia Greenfield, a psychology professor, believes that focusing more on visual media can reduce critical thinking. She says that less reading might lead to less critical thinking because people focus more on real-time media and multitasking. There is no clear answer yet on how technology affects critical thinking. Technology has changed how people think, says Greenfield, who studied over 50 studies on learning and technology. Reading helps thinking and imagination in ways that video games and TV do not. However, visual media can improve some types of information processing. Most visual media do not allow time for reflection or imagination, which can lead to underachievement, especially in young people. How society views technology affects how it sees critical thinking. Video games and cognition show this conflict. James Paul Gee, an educational psychology professor, says video games can be good for learning. Games like Sim City and Civilization teach decision-making and analytical skills. They allow players to explore ideas in virtual worlds. In the digital age, as reading and math scores decline, we need to understand how technology affects thinking and analysis.'

Matthew Crawford is a motorcycle mechanic who used to work in an office. He became unhappy with office life and decided to write about how we should live. His first book talked about the benefits of manual work. His latest book is about dealing with modern life. He got the idea for this book when he noticed ads on a credit card machine while shopping. Crawford realized that these ads are hard to ignore and take our attention away from what we want to think about. This makes it difficult to remember conversations or think clearly. Because of this, people try to avoid interruptions and stop talking to strangers.
Crawford says we often see the world through things like video games and phone apps, which can control our desires. Many people are worried about this. For example, some office workers complain about emails but spend their free time checking them. Studies show that just seeing a phone on a table can distract us. There is no proof yet that our attention spans are shorter, but we are more aware of other things we could be doing.
Crawford believes technology has made it easy for us to focus on ourselves. We prefer texting friends instead of talking to them. This can make us lose important social connections. He gives an example of a gym where people used to share music, but now everyone listens to their own music with earphones. This change has made the gym less social.
Crawford suggests two solutions. First, we need rules to reduce noise and distractions in public places. More importantly, he thinks we should do skilled activities that connect us with the real world. For example, cooking, playing ice hockey, or racing motorcycles require focus and dealing with real situations. These activities help us use our judgment and connect with others. They show that digital experiences are not as fulfilling as real ones. Crawford says it's important to find ways to use our judgment and focus on what matters. This helps us resist distractions and pay attention to important things.

"‘What do you do for a living?’ is a common question. We often define ourselves by our jobs. Usually, we answer this question in a few words. But when you are a philosopher, like me, it is a bit harder. Saying you are a philosopher can sound pretentious. People might think you claim to know some special truth. This is not true; philosophers are just like everyone else. But this idea makes me pause. Why do people think this way about philosophers? One reason is that philosophers are seen as people who judge others and value intellectual life. The Greek philosopher Aristotle said that a life of thinking, or a philosophical life, was the best life. Few modern philosophers agree, but philosophy is still linked with thinking deeply. Another Greek philosopher, Socrates, said, ‘the unexamined life is not worth living’. He meant that just accepting what everyone else does is not satisfying. Our ability to think about the world helps us control our lives and make decisions. But living an examined life does not mean reading many philosophy books or thinking deeply all the time. It means looking closely at our daily experiences to see if they are important. It does not mean living away from society to think clearly. In fact, to help guide our lives, examining life is practical and should be shared with others. This is part of a good life. Another reason people misunderstand philosophers is that academic philosophy has become distant from real life. This is not all the philosophers' fault. University funding and evaluations focus on expensive and hard-to-access journals. So, philosophers often only talk to other experts in their field. To outsiders, philosophy can seem far from reality. If philosophers once tried to change this view, many have stopped. The university system created this isolated environment, and academics have supported it. As some areas of philosophy focus on very specific debates, explaining them to non-experts is hard. Philosophy, in some cases, has moved away from society. This needs to change. I sometimes call myself an ‘ethicist’ because I work in ethics, which is about evaluating human actions. But recently, I feel this title is not enough. Ethics is often seen as linked to rules and laws. This is a new idea in philosophy: ethics now often means applied ethics, which looks at the fairness of social practices. Ethicists today decide if an action is ‘ethical’ or acceptable. These are important questions, and I often think about them. But philosophy is more than this. A discussion might start with whether downloading films illegally is wrong (it is) and then look at responsibility, our views on art, and consumerism. Philosophy helps us look closely at our actions and beliefs. Sometimes we find what we already know; other times, we see our beliefs are hard to justify. By examining these ideas, we help everyone."

People who love food, like foodies, chefs, and gourmands, might think that thinking deeply about what and how we eat can make eating more enjoyable. However, in history, philosophers have often talked about food to explain other ideas. For example, they might use eating as a way to talk about learning. Sometimes, discussions that seem to be about food are actually about other topics. 
An interesting example is the ancient Greek philosopher Epicurus. He talked about finding pleasure and avoiding pain in many parts of life. But today, his name is often linked with a love for eating and drinking. We see his name used in restaurants and food shops because people think it adds value to their products. 
Food is social and cultural. It comes from history and is shared with others in our communities. These communities give us people to eat with and help grow and distribute food. We interact with food more than any other product, making it an important topic to think about. 
Once food is made, critics talk and write about it. But why are they so important? One philosopher says that tasting food is not a special skill, but good critics are just better at describing tastes. Most studies on perception focus on sight, not taste, and this should change. 
Food also has an aesthetic side. We say paintings or music are beautiful, but not usually food. Some philosophers think food should be part of discussions about beauty, like art or poetry. But food is eaten and disappears, unlike art, which lasts over time. 
There are many ethical questions about food. What should we eat: organic, free-range, local, vegetarian, or non-GMO? Our choices show our beliefs, and philosophers ask why we make these choices. 
Cooking at home and in restaurants is different. Home cooks have a duty to their guests because of love and friendship. In homes, everyone shares food and companionship. Professional cooks have duties to their employers and the food, so their kitchens are not open to everyone. 
A recent essay called ‘Diplomacy of the Dish’ looks at how food can help bridge cultural gaps. This happens in two ways. First, we can appreciate other cultures by enjoying their food. Second, eating together helps us connect with people from other cultures, a practice used in international diplomacy. The essay includes many interesting examples and stories, making food philosophy lively for readers.

Rob Daviau, from the US, creates 'legacy' board games. He thought the board games he played as a child were not fun or challenging anymore. So, he wondered how board games could change. Could they have a story? Could choices in one game affect the next? He changed a classic game called Risk to make Risk Legacy. In this game, choices made during play have a lasting effect. Players might have to tear up cards, write on the board, or open packets with new rules. The game is played over several sessions, and past actions become part of the game. Daviau said: ‘You could point to the board and say: “Right here! You did this!”’
Daviau then worked on a legacy version of Pandemic, a popular game where players try to stop diseases. His next project was SeaFall, a game set in the age of sail (16th – mid 19th century). Players explore and conquer new lands. Legacy game designers must think about all player choices to keep the story together. They use testers to see how the game plays out. Jaime Barriga, a tester for SeaFall, said: ‘It takes a lot of time. Sometimes the first few games are great, but later it gets shaky, and then it breaks. Then you have to fix everything.’
Legacy games were not expected to be popular. Daviau thought it would be a small interest. ‘I thought it was different and good,’ he said. ‘But it’s strange and breaks many rules. I thought only a few people would like it.’ However, many players, like Russell Chapman, loved it. He thinks it’s a big step forward in game design. ‘It’s a new level of excitement,’ he said. ‘There’s nothing more exciting for a board gamer than learning a new game or way to play.’
Another fan, Ben Hogg, liked the adventure of legacy games. ‘At first, I was worried about changing and ruining the board,’ he said. ‘But Pandemic Legacy changed that. Most people don’t watch the same movie twice. You’re buying an experience. It’s like the stories in video games.’ The legacy format is also like popular TV series. Daviau wanted to be a TV writer but became a game designer. He still loves telling stories. Pandemic creator Matt Leacock compares legacy design to writing a novel. ‘You need to know how it ends and starts,’ he said. ‘But you also need more than just an outline.’
Daviau feels proud of his idea but wants others to explore it too. He thinks gamers will soon want something new. Colby Dauch, from the publisher of SeaFall, believes the legacy format changes how we think about board games.

'One night, an octopus named Inky escaped from his tank at New Zealand’s National Aquarium. He moved across the floor and went into a drain that led to the Pacific Ocean. This story was shared a lot online and seemed like something from a children's movie. People enjoy stories like this because they like to think animals are like humans. This is especially true for octopuses, which are very smart but look very different from us. Octopuses can open jars, recognize faces, use coconut shells as armor, and even play in a smart way.
Some people think it's unscientific to say animals are like humans, but Dr. Frans de Waal, who studies animals like gorillas and chimpanzees, disagrees. He says that not recognizing human-like traits in animals, which he calls "anthropodenial," is more common. He has studied animal behavior for many years and found that animals can do many things we thought only humans could do, like thinking about the past and future, showing empathy, and understanding others' motives. Animals are smarter than we often think.
In the past, people thought animals were smart. In medieval Europe, animals could even be put on trial for crimes. In the 19th century, naturalists looked for connections between human and animal intelligence. Charles Darwin, who developed the theory of evolution, said that the difference between humans and animals is one of degree, not kind.
In the 20th century, behaviorism changed how people viewed animal intelligence. Animals were seen as machines that responded to stimuli or as robots with instincts. People who thought animals had inner lives were considered unscientific. This view happened at the same time humans were destroying animal habitats and ignoring animal welfare.
Dr. de Waal believes we are now starting to see animal intelligence as similar to human intelligence, though not the same. He says that the best tests for animal intelligence consider the animal's unique traits. For example, squirrels might not do well on human memory tests, but they can remember where they hid nuts. In her book, The Soul of an Octopus, Sy Montgomery says that if an octopus tested human intelligence, it might test us on how many color patterns we can make on our skin. We would fail, and the octopus might think we are not smart.
Dr. de Waal is not sure if Inky really found his way to the ocean. He knows that stories like Inky's can help people appreciate animal intelligence. He once did an experiment to see if capuchin monkeys feel envy. When some monkeys got cucumbers and others got grapes, the monkeys with cucumbers got upset. The study was published in a scientific journal, but a video of the experiment convinced more people. This shows how our minds work in interesting ways.'

'Robotics, once only in science fiction, is now a big change like the industrial revolution. Robots have been used in car and factory work for many years. Experts say robots will soon be used in many more areas, but many countries are not ready for this change. Most people think robots will do most jobs in the next 50 years, but they also believe their own jobs will still exist. This is not true: all job areas will be affected by robots soon. For example, an Australian company, Fastbrick Robotics, made a robot called Hadrian X that can lay 1,000 bricks in one hour, a job that takes two people almost a day. In San Francisco, Simbe Robotics created Tally, a robot that checks if supermarket shelves are stocked and priced correctly. People who support robots say they will create new jobs for technicians and programmers. Critics say we should not forget the importance of human skills at work. Dr. Jing Bing Zhang, an expert in robotics, studies how robots are changing jobs. His team says that soon, one-third of robots will be smarter and work with humans. In three years, many big companies will have a chief robotics officer, and some governments will have laws about robots. In five years, salaries in robotics will go up by 60%, but many jobs will be empty because there are not enough skilled workers. Zhang says lower-skilled workers will be affected and need to retrain. New robots will also be made for homes and will interact with us in new ways. This is a big chance for companies, but also a challenge because we need new rules for safety and privacy. With many jobs at risk, education is important to prepare for the future. Countries need more graduates in science, technology, engineering, and maths (STEM) to stay competitive.'

George Mallory, a famous mountaineer, once answered a reporter's question about why he wanted to climb Mount Everest by saying, "Because it's there." The reporter's question showed that many people want to understand why someone would do something so dangerous. Mallory's answer might inspire some people to follow their dreams and face the unknown. It also reminds us that climbing can be about adventure and fun. 
In 1967, Bolivian writer Tejada-Flores wrote an important essay called ‘Games that Climbers Play’. He described seven different types of climbing activities, each with its own rules. He said that the style of climbing, like using more or less equipment, should follow the rules of the specific climbing activity. Over the years, this idea has become very popular in Western climbing discussions, from magazines to debates.
Many climbers love climbing because it makes them feel free. However, climbing can also be limiting, like when a storm traps you in a tent. This shows a paradox in climbing: it can feel both freeing and restricting. But some say that having fewer choices can make life simpler, which is a kind of freedom.
US rock climber Joe Fitschen suggests a different question: "Why do people climb?" He believes climbing is in our genes and that we naturally want to take on challenges, even if they are risky. So, the joy of climbing is more about biology than logic.
US academic Brian Treanor wrote that climbing can help develop important virtues like courage, humility, and respect for nature. He thinks these virtues are important in our modern world, which often avoids risks. Climbing can help people develop traits that are useful in everyday life.
Some climbers believe that those who climb without help from others or technology must be very committed to succeed. Experts Ebert and Robinson argued that climbing is more impressive when done independently, without things like bottled oxygen. This idea caused some controversy because it might encourage climbers to take unnecessary risks.
Climbing can also be understood by looking beyond Western ideas. Many climbers talk about being "in the moment" or "in the zone" while climbing. The physical effort, meditation, and problem-solving involved in climbing are similar to techniques in Zen philosophy, which aims for a state of perfect peace. This is another reason why people might be drawn to climbing.

'For over sixty years, the pianist Alfred Brendel became very important in classical music. He was a serious and thoughtful person who played and recorded many famous European piano pieces. He wrote and played a lot, but he did not teach much. People who knew him well saw that he could be fun, but he did not show this side in his concerts. His life was full of study, travel, and performances. Then, about four or five years ago, a young boy named Kit Armstrong came to one of Brendel’s concerts and asked for lessons. At first, Brendel did not take him seriously. He had taught very few students and did not plan to start now. He said, ‘You don’t need a mountain guide to teach a child how to walk.’ But there was something special about Kit, who was about 14 years old then. Brendel listened to him play. Brendel said, ‘He played very well and from memory. Then he gave me a CD of a small concert he did, where he played so beautifully that I thought, “I have to make time for him.” It was a performance that took you from the first to the last note. It’s rare to find a musician with this kind of understanding and skill.’ As Brendel is leaving the public stage, Kit is starting to enter it, but Brendel is careful that Kit does not get too tired too soon. Kit, now 19, is always busy when not in lessons – learning new languages, studying math, writing computer code, or playing tennis. His mother is always watching over him. He also composes music. ‘This is very important,’ Brendel says. ‘Learning to read music well is easier if you try to write music yourself. I noticed that Kit has an amazing memory and is very good at reading music at first sight. But more important is his ability to listen to his own playing, his sensitivity to sound, and his ability to listen to me when I explain something. He not only understands what I mean, but he can do it. And when I tell him one thing in a piece, he will do it everywhere in the piece where it appears later.’ Brendel stops and looks serious. ‘I don’t want to raise any expectations. I get upset if newspapers try to do this. One article called him the future great pianist of the 21st century. It’s the worst thing. You don’t say that in a newspaper. It has done a lot of harm. Like many talented young players, he can play some things very well, but others need more time and experience. It would be bad if a critic expected the greatest perfection.’ Now at 80 years old, it is nice to see Brendel more relaxed in his later years. He explains, ‘When I was very young, I didn’t want to be famous in five years, but I wanted to have done certain things by the age of 50. When I was 50, I thought I had done most of those things, but there was still room for more, so I continued. Although I don’t have the physical strength now, in my mind, there are always things happening, all sorts of pieces that I’ve never played. I don’t play now, but it’s a very nice new career.’'

'When I was little, I always thought gardens were magical places. My Grandad's garden was not in a dirty city. It was next to a river and went down gently to the water. You couldn't reach the river, but you could hear the water and the birds in the trees. I thought all gardens were like this – places to escape, find peace, and be alone. Grandad's garden was simple. He didn't have a greenhouse like some neighbors. Their greenhouses were made from old window frames, with plastic patches where glass was broken. At home, my father was often quiet. He wasn't without humor, though. He liked to say, 'It's immaterial to me,' instead of 'I don't mind.' He probably wished he had done more with his life. He left school without qualifications and became a plumber. He didn't love plumbing; it was just his job. He wasn't very ambitious, but once he and Mum thought about moving to Canada, but it didn't happen. He was good at fixing things around the house. He could make bookshelves or cupboards very well. My parents only moved house once. But my mother liked to change furniture often. Just when you got used to one chair, another would appear. The biggest change was when we got a piano. I wanted to like it, but it scared me. I liked the brass candlesticks on it, but my mother thought they were too fancy and took them away. I was never allowed to play the piano. My sister got lessons instead. When I asked my mother why I didn't get lessons, she said, 'You'd never have practiced.' I liked the river best. I would go there with a fishing net and old sandals. I would find a spot, take off my sandals, and look for fish to catch. After trying to keep them alive at home, I would put them back in the river. I wanted to leave school as soon as I could, but it seemed impossible until my father said, 'There's a job for an apprentice gardener in the Parks Department. I thought you might be interested.' My father might have wanted me to be a carpenter, but I think he saw my love for gardening. Even though he didn't like gardening, he saw my passion for it.'

Lawrence MacEwen crouches down on his Scottish island, the Isle of Muck. I do the same. A strong wind from the Atlantic threatens to blow us off the cliff and into the ocean below. MacEwen’s sheepdog, Tie, comes over, and MacEwen gently pets him. The wind is strong, but MacEwen is comfortable here on his island. He is giving me a tour of the area. Pointing north, he shouts, ‘That island is Eigg. The one to the west is the Isle of Rum. It gets twice as much rain as we do.’ I see heavy clouds over Rum’s mountains. ‘Just beyond Rum is the island of Soay.’ Suddenly, MacEwen says, ‘I have sheep to move,’ as rain comes our way. We walk down the slopes, and he tells me about the island: Muck is three km long and half as wide; its geese eat a lot of grass; and the MacEwens have lived here for 3000 years. Moving the sheep stops our conversation. Tie, the sheepdog, is trying to gather the sheep but is not doing well. ‘Away to me, Tie. Away to me,’ MacEwen says, meaning the dog should go to the right. Tie doesn’t listen and goes straight into the flock, causing confusion. ‘Tie,’ MacEwen says, sounding disappointed. The dog looks ashamed. The Isle of Muck is mostly run by the MacEwen family. Lawrence runs the farm with his wife, Jenny; their son Colin manages the island cottages; and their daughter Mary runs the island hotel, Port Mor, with her husband, Toby. Mary and Toby like that their two boys can explore the island and sail small boats in the summer. ‘They go out and come back only when they’re hungry.’ But island life has challenges. For example, electricity is only available part of the time. On my first evening, I wait for the lights to turn on. The next morning, I find Mary preparing breakfast with a flashlight. I get used to it, along with no mobile phone service. ‘There is mobile reception on the hill,’ Mary tells me. ‘Most people last a couple of days, then just put the phone away.’ So I do too. Everything on Muck seems surprising. Today, the boat brings groceries and three musicians with instruments. Their concert in the island’s tearoom is a big success, with everyone tapping their boots to the music. That night, by a warm fire as it rains outside, Lawrence MacEwen tells me how he met his wife, Jenny. ‘Her father bought a small farm on the isle of Soay from a newspaper ad, without seeing it. He’d never been to Scotland. Jenny was sent to manage it.’ Did Jenny know about farming? ‘She had good typing skills.’ I go to bed with rain and wake up to more rain. But I eat well, with almost all the food coming from the island. Mary sends me to fisherman Sandy Mathers for fresh fish. I bring it back to Mary at the kitchen door. By 7 pm, our fish is on the table, and it is delicious. Also uncertain is my ferry ride the next morning to another island. Many ferries had been canceled in the past two months because of high seas. If my ferry didn’t come, I’d be stuck on Muck for two more days. Which, now, phone or no phone, I secretly hoped for.

'At first, the game design industry was mostly for computer scientists and people who taught themselves. It was often seen as just a hobby for young people. But now, the video games industry is taken seriously. Experts are not surprised. Making video games is not easy. Games that come out after new movies need many team members and months of hard work. Like many industries, it is hard to enter, but it is growing. Jim Donelly, from an online games magazine, says: ‘It’s hard to make progress in big companies or to influence big games. But the industry needs game designers more than ever. Not just directors, but also people who design parts of the game.’ So, how can you enter this competitive industry? Many companies want people with a computer science degree, but Jim disagrees. ‘The only way is to make games. The tools are available. You need to create something to get a job. Game design is more a way of life than a job.’ Another expert, John Field, sees other options. ‘Just doing it is important, but it’s more complicated. Many want to work in games, but few meet the industry’s needs. Even fewer have the talent, skills, and vision to contribute to this changing field.’ Can you do it alone? ‘Maybe, but it’s hard,’ says John. ‘A good postgraduate course can help and give support. Most game designers start as programmers or artists and move up. They are interested in all entertainment media and arts. They may have worked a few years after graduation and decided games are their passion. They are not just fans but are excited about the future of games. Connections can help too. Networking is important to get ahead in games.’ The idea of a young boy playing games all day is outdated. Now, games are seen as a serious medium. Families play on interactive consoles. Smartphones offer many new games through apps and social media. John believes there is room for growth. ‘Games are popular with large audiences. They are also a great way to learn. I see many possibilities and opportunities in this big area.’

'Since I was a child, all I wanted to do was play football. My dad encouraged me to play, but he didn't force me. I had a friend whose dad was very pushy. He always told him what he couldn't do. My friend could have been a good player, but he stopped wanting to play and never played football again. I'm glad it didn't happen to me, but I know it could have been different. When I score a great goal from far away, people say it's just luck, but it's not. I've practiced shooting from a distance since I was a kid. Only by practicing can you score amazing goals. The best players in the world have natural talent, but they also practice for many years. Sometimes young players crash into each other, but I learned technique. When I teach kids, I tell them to enjoy learning skills. I used to play every sport at school, like rounders, baseball, athletics, and basketball. I know education is important, but football was all I thought about then. The teachers did a good job, but I didn't notice it at the time. I don't want it to be like that for my son. We try to read him books, even though he's too young to sit still. I hope he doesn't just want to kick them around like I did. At the start of my professional football career, the manager made sacrifices so young players could join the first team, but he didn't make a big deal about it. He didn't say, 'This is your big chance,' but we knew it was. I scored in the first game of the season, but we lost, and a TV presenter said, 'You can't win anything with kids.' That made us realize how much we had to do. We had some doubts, but we believed in ourselves as a team. I rely on close friends and family a lot. Having a lot of money can cause problems. People say, 'I can't believe you let your mother keep working.' Of course, I've helped my parents with money. I paid off their house loan and bought them a car last Christmas. My family is strong, and they would be upset if they thought they should be on my payroll. My mum doesn't earn much as a hairdresser, but she loves her job. I like using my money to help people around me. I have a lot of money, but not as much as people think, and it doesn't solve everything. After I stop playing, I want to take a year off to do things I couldn't do before. I want to go skiing right after I stop playing. I can't do that now because if I break a leg skiing and can't play football, I wouldn't be insured.'

'We were living at Reef Point because of Sam Carter. Sam was my father’s agent in Los Angeles. He offered to find us a cheap place to live because my father couldn’t write in Los Angeles. Sam was worried about losing clients and money. During the summer, the beach was empty because sea fogs covered the sun. Reef Point was not popular with day trippers. The road was not nice, and the resort of La Carmella was nearby. People with money stayed there. Only people with little money or those who loved surfing came to Reef Point. But now, with the hot weather, many people came. After months alone, we were surrounded by people and activities. My father was busy trying to write a script on time and was in a bad mood. Most days, I went to the beach with a book and Rusty, my dog. When we first moved to Reef Point, we didn’t have a dog, but Rusty decided to stay with us. I tried to chase him away, but he always came back. One morning, I gave him water, and my father threw a boot at him, but not seriously. Rusty knew this and stayed closer. I asked my father, ‘Who do you think he belongs to? He seems to think he belongs to us.’ My father said, ‘You’re wrong, Jane. He thinks we belong to him.’ Rusty loved the beach and often brought me things he found. Sometimes, he brought things like a new sneaker or a bright beach towel, and I had to return them to their owners. He liked to swim too and always came with me, even though I swam faster and farther. He never got discouraged. We had been swimming that day. My father, after finishing his script, went to Los Angeles to deliver it. Rusty and I spent the afternoon in and out of the sea. But now, as the sun was setting, it was getting cooler, and we watched the surfers. They had been surfing all day and didn’t seem to get tired. They chose a wave and stood, balancing as the water curved up, riding the wave until it reached the sand. One surfer caught my eye. She had a style that made the others look clumsy. She decided to stop and rode in on a final wave. ‘Hi,’ she said, ‘why didn’t you join us?’ ‘I haven’t got a surfboard.’ ‘You could get one.’ ‘No money.’ ‘You’re British, aren’t you? You visiting?’ ‘No, I live here.’ ‘Is your father American?’ ‘No. He came here to write the film script of a novel he wrote.’ ‘No kidding? Have I heard of him? What’s his name?’ ‘Rufus Marsh.’ ‘You mean, Tall as the Morning?’ I nodded. ‘I read that book cover to cover.’ She looked at me with new interest, and I thought this was how it always was. They were friendly but never interested until I mentioned Tall as the Morning.'

Violet Hetherington was standing in a long queue at the dock in Southampton, waiting to board the Queen Caroline. Her friend Annie had advised her to arrive late to avoid waiting, but this advice turned out to be wrong. An announcement said there was a problem with the computer system, which made the passengers upset. They had paid a lot for this trip and expected better service. Violet felt like leaving, especially when she realized she had lost her phone. She couldn't call the taxi company to check if she left it there because all her contacts were in the phone. Her son Harry always warned her about this. 
Violet asked a couple behind her if she could use their phone. She called Harry and left a message asking him to ask her neighbor Kristina to check if the phone was in her flat. If it wasn't there, she would have trouble finding the numbers she needed in New York. Part of her felt relieved, but she didn't tell Harry that. Harry thought he was wiser than his mother, while her younger son Daniel was more understanding because he was forgetful too.
Finally, the queue moved, and Violet handed over her travel documents to board the ship. Her heart sank when she saw the ship's foyer, which looked like a hotel trying too hard to be fancy. There were fake walnut panels, shiny chandeliers, and carpets like those in airports. She took the elevator, crowded with tired passengers, to the twelfth floor. Thankfully, her room had the balcony she wanted. She had paid a lot to ensure she could see the sea, ignoring Annie's advice to wait for a last-minute deal.

When John Maloof bought a box of old photo negatives at an auction, he didn't know he was starting a journey into the mystery of Vivian Maier. Maloof was looking for pictures for a book about the Portage Park neighborhood in Chicago, USA. Instead, he found 30,000 images by Maier, a street photographer with a talent for capturing interesting pictures. Since then, Maloof has collected many of Maier’s belongings. In his attic, he has her cameras, 2,000 rolls of film, 3,000 prints, and 100,000 negatives, along with many 8mm movies and audiotapes. One morning, Maloof looked at all of it and realized he had found something special by chance. ‘When I bought all this, I had no idea what it was,’ Maloof said. ‘I’m a third-generation flea market seller and could have easily just sold it all to someone else.’ Maloof and his friend Anthony Rydzon have been trying to learn more about Maier’s life. They talked to families who hired her as a nanny and people from the shop where she developed her film. Maier was born in 1926 in New York and spent much of her childhood in France. In 1951, she returned to New York and in 1956 moved to Chicago to work as a nanny. Maier was known to be private and a bit unusual, always carrying a camera. She wore large coats, big hats, and strong shoes. ‘On her day off, she would leave with her camera in the morning and return late at night,’ said Maren Baylaender, whose husband hired Maier to care for his daughter. ‘She was private but had strong opinions about movies and politics.’ Maier knew a lot about theater and movies. She wasn’t very social, but she wasn’t afraid to walk the streets with her camera and talk to people, some of whom she recorded on audiotape. She seemed very focused on her ‘second job’ of documenting the world around her. ‘She was a true artist and followed her dreams,’ said Rydzon. ‘She didn’t let anyone stop her.’ Maier’s work was pure art; she didn’t do it for money. Her photos often showed women, children, the elderly, the poor, and abstract scenes. ‘What is interesting about Vivian is that there are so many fascinating pictures,’ said photography expert Larry Silverman. He sees the influence of other photographers in her work and wonders if she developed her style on her own. ‘Was Vivian very skilled or did she take ideas from others?’ Maloof often wonders if he will ever look through all the negatives, which he keeps in three tall, fireproof cabinets. The funny thing is, he wasn’t interested in photography until he found Maier’s work. Inspired by her photos, Maloof started taking his own pictures. ‘As I learned more about photography and looked at her work again, I realized it wasn’t just about cityscapes. It was about people, street scenes, and composition,’ he said. ‘There was so much more to her work than I thought, and I realized I had found something very important. Now, our goal is to make her name known. To get Vivian Maier into the history books.'

'When a novel is called ambitious, it often means it didn't fully succeed. But this is not true for Eleanor Catton’s book, The Luminaries. I talked to her in the UK when her book was very popular. She was calm, even though she was still in her twenties. She had just come from Germany and was going back to New Zealand the next day. She told me a story about being stopped at passport control and asked to prove she was a writer. She showed her novel to the officer. The officer asked, ‘What’s it about?’ This is not an easy question for an author. The Luminaries is set in the 1860s in New Zealand. There are a series of crimes, and 12 men meet to solve them. The story becomes very complex. Catton said she wanted to write a murder mystery, not a historical novel, but found the past gave more chances for complications. The book is over 800 pages long because she wanted to give each of the 20 main characters enough attention. When I ask how it feels to be successful at a young age, she says, ‘It’s nice coming from a small country because everyone feels the success is partly theirs. There’s a family feeling at home, and I got a lot of support from people.’ Then she adds, ‘What is annoying is when people think my book is not a serious work.’ ‘I wanted to write the book in the shape of a spiral. Each part is half the length of the one before it,’ said Catton. The book speeds up as it goes. I ask if it matters if the reader notices this. ‘I wanted to create a book with patterns that didn’t matter, but if you cared, you could see them.’ Despite the structure, The Luminaries is an exciting murder mystery. Surprisingly, she didn’t plan the story beforehand. ‘I would write myself into a corner and then see how I could get out of it.’ She also wanted the book to be fun for the reader. We talk about her love of TV drama series. I ask if she might be interested in writing for TV. ‘That could be cool,’ she says. She is enthusiastic and laughs often. She loves talking about her work and New Zealand. ‘When I come to Britain, I notice how my imagination changes just by being in a different place. I see why writers move away from New Zealand to busy places, to be around more people.’ But for now, New Zealand will still be her home. I hope it gives her ideas for more novels.'

'As a boy, Jonny Kinkead liked to make things in his dad’s garage and play the guitar. These two hobbies became his job for the last forty years: making steel-string, acoustic guitars by hand. ‘I’m still amazed by the guitar,’ he says. ‘How can two pieces of wood make such a beautiful sound? And by using different types of wood, you get different sounds. It still surprises me.’ Jonny learned to play his brother’s guitar when he was eleven. At sixteen, he wanted to learn the bass guitar. ‘Some people would get a holiday job and save money to buy one,’ he says. ‘But I thought if you wanted something, you made it yourself. I studied guitars and learned how different shapes and woods changed the sound, and how to build them.’ The bass was the first instrument Jonny made from scratch, but he and his brothers had been making other things for a long time. ‘We drew model boats and planes and then built them, so I knew the process. My father taught us how to use tools. I also fixed and changed instruments for my friends.’ Jonny’s bass guitar was good, but he didn’t think about a career in guitar-making. ‘I also liked painting and sculpture,’ he says. After school, he chose to study architecture at university. ‘Architecture involves design, which I liked, and being an architect seemed like a good idea,’ he remembers. But halfway through, he left the course. ‘I was too individualistic,’ he says. ‘But I left with a better idea of what I wanted to do. I still liked sculpture, but I realized guitar-making is like sculpture – it’s about shaping sound. And I thought it might be more practical than pure art because you make things people use.’ Since then, Jonny has made guitars for a living. For the first ten years, he also cleaned windows part-time. The first guitars he sold only covered the cost of materials, but as he became known as a great guitar-maker, he could charge more. Even now, almost forty years later, Jonny says he is ‘still just making a living’. He admits he can only make ten guitars a year, which limits his earnings. In the early years, he worked hard to become known. He went to music festivals most weekends and got musicians to try his guitars and talk about him. He also had to learn how to price his instruments – when musicians asked, he didn’t have an answer because it wasn’t natural for him. Jonny thinks it’s easier for new guitar-makers in the UK today. ‘When I started, people thought the only good acoustic guitars were made in the USA,’ he says. ‘UK-made guitars weren’t seen as real, even though we’ve always had good courses and skills here. But now our hand-made guitars have the reputation they deserve.’ Jonny says you can learn valuable techniques in the classroom, and he thinks new instrument-makers should take courses. However, he also believes there is no substitute for trial and error. ‘Look at other instruments, see what works or doesn’t, and try different things,’ Jonny says. ‘If you make the back too thin or too thick, it won’t sound good. If someone else teaches you, you learn one way, but if you teach yourself, like I did, you learn everything.’

'When talking about English conversation, we often start with the weather. This is a tradition, and many writers mention the famous comment by Dr. Johnson, an eighteenth-century diarist, who said, ‘When two Englishmen meet, their first talk is of the weather’. This is still true today. Many people try to explain why English people talk so much about the weather, but they often get it wrong. They think English people talk about the weather because they are very interested in it. For example, the American writer Bill Bryson says that English weather is not exciting, so he doesn’t understand why people talk about it so much. He notes that England doesn’t have extreme weather like tornadoes or blizzards. On the other hand, English broadcaster Jeremy Paxman argues that the weather is interesting because it is unpredictable. He says that living near the ocean and a continent means you never know what weather you will get. However, my research shows that both Bryson and Paxman miss the point. English people don’t really talk about the weather because they care about it. Instead, weather talk is a way to help English people start conversations. Phrases like ‘Nice day, isn’t it?’ or ‘Ooh, isn’t it cold?’ are not really about the weather. They are greetings or ways to start a conversation. This is similar to how monkeys groom each other to bond socially. There are specific times when English people use weather talk. It can be a greeting, a way to start a conversation, or a topic to fill a silence. This happens often, so people think English people are obsessed with the weather. An English conversation might start with weather talk, use it to break the ice, and return to it if there is a pause. This makes it seem like English people talk about nothing else.'

Alice Leader was standing in front of Hadrian’s Wall in Britain. She was trying to explain to her class of 12- and 13-year-olds how amazing it was that the Romans built something 120 km long and 5 meters high about 1900 years ago. The students were interested because they chose this trip over trips to Spain, Greece, or France. But they wanted to know why the wall was built, and Alice felt her answers were not good enough. When she couldn't find a historical novel to help explain life at the Wall in Roman times, she decided to write one herself. After teaching for 31 years, Alice started a new career as an author in 2001. She felt it was a big change. ‘Teaching is like acting, it’s a performance every day and very tiring. Writing is exciting but not as exhausting. My old teaching friends are jealous because I still connect with children through my books.’ Alice wants her novels to fill a gap in children’s fiction. ‘Many books for teenagers today are about negative experiences. They are well written,’ she adds, ‘but many are dark or total fantasy, like Harry Potter. My books are different.’ Alice always taught English and History together, like teaching about ancient Greece with the novel Tale of Troy. She loves seeing children go from bored to interested and from not understanding to understanding. She sees her writing as an extension of teaching. She was inspired to write her first novel because there was a gap in the market and because her two sons were leaving home. Her head teacher also suggested she try a creative writing course. Alice was surprised. ‘I’d been teaching for 25 years. She said it would be good for me. But I didn’t want to spend my summer holiday doing a course I didn’t think I needed.’ Before the course, she had to send her best piece of fiction. She quickly wrote a story about a Roman couple and their baby. Three hours and 30 pages later, she sent it in and was accepted. During the course, other students liked her story and suggested she publish it. With only 8,000 report cards as proof of her writing skills, she asked her head teacher for a year off to write her first novel. Alice’s husband, Zachary Leader, is a critic and editor, and he helped her edit the novel. Alice says, ‘My mother-in-law thinks we’re rival authors, but we complement each other. He works with what I’ve written – he reads a chapter and changes the sentence structure, and if it’s not working, he suggests changing the words. My instinct is to keep adding more scenes. That’s the difference between a fiction writer and an editor or critic.’

'To raise money for charity, a newspaper and a TV company asked brothers Jonny and Alistair Brownlee, who are champion triathletes, to join a special race. This race would be man against car, and brother against brother. In the wild and hilly Yorkshire Dales in northern England, Jonny and his younger brother Ali would race to the same place. Jonny would drive a car on roads, and Ali would ride a mountain bike across the countryside. ‘I’m looking forward to it,’ Jonny said at the start line. ‘I’ve never done anything like this before: it’s exciting! These roads have beautiful views – and it’s very cold now, so I’ll be warm in the car.’ Alistair was also excited. He wore full winter cycling clothes, while Jonny wore jeans and a sweatshirt. Alistair was confident. ‘To be honest,’ he said, ‘I’ve seen his driving before, so I’m not sure he’ll make it. I might stop for a cup of tea halfway up.’ The race started at the beautiful Semerwater lake in Wensleydale and would finish at Yorkshire’s highest road, Fleet Moss, 350 metres up. It might be easy for the car, but Alistair’s first miles had a steep hill, so he had a hard start. After a quick handshake, they began. Alistair rode his bike up the hill and across the countryside to Fleet Moss. Jonny got in the car and drove on the road. They would see each other again at the finish line. Who would get there first? Jonny’s confidence was tested right away. Just 15 seconds into the drive, he faced his first problem. A giant tractor came out of a field and onto the road. ‘Welcome to Yorkshire,’ he said to the cameraman in his car. ‘If Alistair beats me, it’s because of this farmer!’ After the tractor was gone, Jonny was back on track, driving into the morning mist. Alistair was having trouble with the hill. A few miles in, he had to get off his bike and carry it up the hill, past walls and over fences. Sheep watched him as he kept going with the bike on his shoulders. Finally, he reached the top. On the other side, there was open ground. With the sun out, he could show his skills. Head down, feet on the pedals, Alistair gained speed. In the car, Jonny faced another problem. The villages in Yorkshire are old, and the roads are not made for speed. Jonny tried to drive through a very narrow corner. The car slowed down, then went through a stream on the road. After the last village, the car was on a straight path to the finish line. Neither brother knew how close the other was. As Jonny sped through the final straight to Fleet Moss, Alistair was crossing his last field and back on the road – coming to the finish from the other side. Head down, legs moving fast… and then he stopped at the line. Alistair looked up. ‘Is he here?’ he asked the crowd. ‘No? Really?’ He raised his arms. ‘Yes!’ Minutes later, the car arrived and Jonny got out. ‘Well done,’ Jonny said, feeling disappointed. ‘I’m gutted.’'

'The silence is what you notice when you play on Centre Court at the Wimbledon tennis championships. You bounce the ball quietly on the soft grass; you toss it up to serve; you hit it and hear the echo of your shot. The trimmed grass, the history, the old stadium, the players in white, and the respectful crowds all make you feel separate from the outside world. The quiet of Centre Court helps my game. In a tennis match, I try hard to focus only on the game and the point I’m playing. The silence is broken by noise when a point ends: applause, cheers, people shouting your name. I hear them, but it feels far away. I don’t notice the fifteen thousand people watching every move my opponent and I make. I am so focused that I forget there are millions watching me around the world as I play Roger Federer in the 2008 Wimbledon final – the biggest match of my life. I always dreamed of playing at Wimbledon. My uncle Toni, my coach, taught me from a young age that this was the biggest tournament. By the time I was 14, I was telling my friends I’d play there one day and win. Before 2008, I played and lost, both times against Federer – in the final the year before, and the year before that. The defeat in 2006 was not so hard. I was just happy to have made it that far at twenty years old. Federer beat me easily because I didn’t believe enough. But losing in 2007 was very hard. I knew I could have done better, and it was my mind that failed me, not my ability. I cried for half an hour in the dressing room. Losing always hurts, but it hurts more when you have a chance and lose it. Toni, a tough coach, usually doesn’t comfort me; he criticizes me even when I win. But I was so upset that he told me not to cry, that there would be more Wimbledons and finals. I told him he didn’t understand, that this was probably my last chance to win. I know how short a professional athlete’s career is, and I want to make the best of it. Every moment counts, but some moments count more, and I let a big one pass in 2007. Toni couldn’t ease my grief. Yet he was right. Another chance came in 2008, just one year later. I was confident I’d learned from that defeat; that my mind would not fail this time. The best sign was my belief that I would win. At dinner with family and friends the night before the final, at the house we rent when I play at Wimbledon, we didn’t talk about the match. I didn’t forbid them from talking about it, but they knew I was already playing the match in my mind. From then until the start of play, that space was mine alone.'

'A young Englishwoman named Jane Goodall arrived in Africa in April 1957. In one of her first letters home, she wrote, "I am living in the Africa I have always dreamed of." Jane spent most of her life in Africa and became known as a citizen, journalist, scientist, activist, and environmentalist. In 1963, Britain's National Geographical Society made Jane Goodall famous with articles and TV shows about her research on chimpanzees. Her fame grew with her own writing, including children's books and the 1971 bestseller "In the Shadow of Man," translated into 47 languages. Jane Goodall is one of the most celebrated female scientists of the 20th century. However, her fame sometimes hides her real achievements. Many stories about her life focus on her adventures and dreams but miss her true work. Jane Goodall should be seen as a pioneer in her field and a leading zoologist. Her main achievement is that she helped us understand the social and emotional lives of chimpanzees. Before her work, people did not know that chimpanzees ate meat or used tools. We also did not know that they have emotions and social systems like humans. Her book, "The Chimpanzees of Gombe" (1986), is a key work in chimpanzee research. Her study of wild apes in Gombe, Nigeria, is considered a great scientific achievement. Jane Goodall changed how we study animals and how we think about ourselves. Even as a child, Jane showed signs of her future career. At five years old, she disappeared one day, and the police were called. She was found with straw in her hair. Jane explained she wanted to see how hens lay eggs, so she hid in a henhouse for five hours. This curiosity was the start of her career as a biologist.'

'During our first conversation, Shirley Ford talks to me using different voices. She sounds like a cheeky 8-year-old boy, the boy’s tired mother, a funny old Scottish woman, and a fast-talking alien. Her voices are known to people who watch children’s TV and cartoons, and to those who have seen computer programs about health and safety. ‘I’ve just done a voiceover about back injuries,’ she says, ‘so I had to quickly learn how to say many medical words.’ Shirley explains what it takes to do voiceovers. ‘Many actors think they can do funny voices, and many probably can,’ she says. ‘But there’s more to it. You have to make the script come alive for an audience who can’t see you. You wouldn’t believe how many famous people want to do voiceover work. Producers invite them to auditions for publicity, but often they don’t get parts because they’re used to acting with their whole bodies.’ After school, Shirley took a drama course, planning a normal acting career. During the course, she sometimes sang jingles for TV adverts. ‘One day,’ she says, ‘the man who ran the recording studio suggested I try out for the part of a rabbit in a cartoon.
