It seemed silly – I hadn’t studied drama to play rabbits – but I tried it for fun and, amazingly, got a big part.’ Shirley realized she could do voices and that voiceover work might be her path. ‘Things just happened for me,’ she says. ‘In my second film, I was lucky to play the main character – and her brother and mother.’ Adult female actors often provide voices for small boys and girls. Their voices are lighter than male actors, and hiring child performers involves complex procedures and many forms, which production companies on tight schedules prefer to avoid. Shirley has learned to create the right sounds from the back of her throat, and to avoid always sounding like the same child, she collects new voices by watching children’s TV. Cartoons are the best part of a job that includes many things from educational videos to vacuum cleaner adverts. ‘Those are hard because you have to sound excited about something you don’t care about, but my years in this job help,’ she says. ‘They’ve taught me that the trick is to smile while you're talking – that makes your voice sound bright and happy. When I have days doing animation work, it feels like a holiday; working with other actors makes a big difference.’ The competition for work is tough, and a good showreel – a recording showing what the artist can do – is essential. ‘It’s definitely worth investing in a strong showreel,’ Shirley says. ‘There are agencies that help voiceover artists make them.’ She says she got where she is – near the top of her profession – through hard work as much as natural talent. ‘Whether it’s making your showreel and taking it to all the film and TV companies, advertising agencies, and recording studios, or just practicing your voices, it’s all about setting goals and not giving up.’ For anyone thinking about a career in voiceovers, Shirley recommends attending ‘specialist workshops – they cover all types of voiceover.’ She also believes a love for human sound is important, describing herself as obsessed with voices and, in a way, becoming the characters she performs. ‘If I’ve been in the studio doing a certain kind of American voice, for example, it can take over me and I’ll be speaking like that for hours, maybe even days afterwards,’ she says. ‘My children have grown up used to their mum talking in completely different voices.’'

'People often ask me how I became a cartoonist. This makes sense because cartooning is a job many dream about as kids, like being a race car driver. But most people give up these dreams and choose more realistic jobs, like being a lawyer or making car parts. The idea of making a living by drawing doodles from school notebooks seems silly. Yet, some people do it. People become cartoonists in different ways, but most have wanted to do it for a long time. For me, I loved comic strips as a child, drew for school publications, and was known as ‘the kid who draws’. I studied graphic design in college and showed my drawings to different companies after graduating. I was lucky to find a newspaper looking for political cartoons. I drew some ideas, they bought them, and soon I was making enough money to live on. You don’t need much to be a cartoonist. You don’t need a degree, much money, or even to be great at drawing. You just need your brain, your hand, and something to draw with. But if it were that easy, there would be as many cartoonists as teachers. The technical skills needed are low, but it’s still a hard job. Don’t try to be a cartoonist unless you feel you can’t do anything else. It’s easier to get a regular job that pays the rent and leaves time for family and hobbies. The more skills you have, the better your chances of making a living with your art. I’ve done political cartoons, comic strips, and comic books. I’ve also been a writer, caricaturist, and sometimes a designer. I don’t say no to any work because you can learn a lot from jobs you don’t really want to do. It helps to be smart, well-read, and curious about everything. What about the business side of being a cartoonist? There was a time when many cartoonists could find regular jobs with newspapers and magazines. But those days are almost over. Today, cartooning is more like running your own business. You have to make and sell your work. Cartoonists with good business skills often do better than those who are very artistic but lack business sense. I often meet people who have never sold a cartoon but are afraid someone will steal their ideas. Some are so worried they won’t show their work to anyone! To protect your work, just draw a ‘c’ for ‘copyright’, put a circle around it, and write your name and the date. But honestly, it’s more likely no one will be interested in your work. If someone does steal a cartoon and it goes viral online, it might actually be a lucky break!'

Twenty years ago, I was moving to a new house and decided to get rid of some things. One of those things was an electric guitar my dad gave me for my 16th birthday. It was a sleek, black, Japanese-made guitar. I usually hate throwing things away, so why did I want to throw this away? I took it to the rubbish dump and was about to throw it on a pile of trash when a young man came up to me. He looked confused and asked, "You’re not just going to throw that away, are you?" I said I was, but I already felt a bit of regret. He asked if he could have it, and I said yes. We went our separate ways. In the years that followed, I often felt sad about what I had done. Then, a few months ago, I got an email that changed my life. It was from a man named Keith Rushton, who deals with and fixes guitars. He wrote, "I’ve got your electric guitar." The guitar had been bought and sold several times since I gave it away. Keith found a name-and-address label on the back. He used my name to find me online and contacted me through the newspaper I work for. He offered to sell it back to me for a fair price. I was so emotional. I had forgotten that my dad used to put name-and-address stickers on everything, including my guitar. My dad would have laughed at this strange story! My parents wanted me to learn the classical guitar in the 1970s because it was very popular. I loved its calming sound, but I didn’t make much progress. So, I switched to the electric guitar, playing simple music. It was also the time of punk music, where you didn’t need to play well to be a rock star. When I got my old guitar back from Keith, I remembered my birthday in 1978 when my parents gave it to me. Holding it again, it felt smooth and smaller than I remembered. I felt the need to stand up and play it with a strap over my shoulder. My fingers remembered where to go, even though I couldn’t draw a diagram of the chords. My fingertips felt the pain of pressing the strings. The electric guitar is not really for playing alone. Now that I’m learning it again, maybe I’ll form a band. My son is learning the saxophone, so maybe we can play together. Or maybe there are others like me, and we could call ourselves ‘The Regainers’!

'Recently, there has been a lot of talk about sleep. When I wrote the book Insomniac, about people who can't sleep, I felt like I was the only one warning about the dangers of not getting enough sleep. Lack of sleep affects our minds, bodies, and moods. People who have trouble sleeping know how important sleep is for our mental, physical, and social health. It's good that sleep is getting more attention now. But what about dreams? I haven't heard much about them. We often lose dreams when we wake up early. The last hour or two of sleep, which we often miss, is mostly REM or ‘Rapid Eye Movement’ sleep, where we dream the most. Our most vivid and emotional dreams happen in REM sleep, just before we wake up. A good sleeper spends about a quarter of their sleep in REM. If someone lives 90 years, they will spend six or seven years in REM. When people are deprived of REM sleep, they have more intense REM sleep the next night. This suggests dreams are important. In 1953, researchers discovered REM sleep. Many agreed with Sigmund Freud, who thought dreams were the best way to understand our minds. But later research did not support this idea. Now, dream studies focus more on the physical origins of dreams. There is still much that dream researchers do not agree on, says Robert Stickgold, a sleep scientist at Harvard University. Dreams are important. At a meeting of the Associated Professional Sleep Society, P.F. Pagel from the University of Colorado Medical School talked about a study. It found that actors, writers, and directors remember and use their dreams better than other people. He concluded that people who are interested in creativity use their dreams more. It makes sense that filmmakers have a strong connection with their dreams because films are very dream-like. But I wondered, are only artistic people using their dreams? Don’t teachers, software designers, and politicians also need to think creatively? Dreams, Stickgold says, help us connect things in new and surprising ways. They help us find new patterns and ideas. For example, Stickgold found that when people are woken up from REM sleep and asked to respond to a word, their answers are more original than when woken from other sleep stages. They make unexpected connections. This is what creativity is, says Stickgold. I write better after intense dreams. Even a troubling dream, even one you can barely remember, seems to help with thinking. On those days, words and images come to me quickly. I don’t know how it works, but it does. But creativity isn’t just for writers or artists. We live in a complex world. We all need our brains to work well. We need to think creatively and flexibly in our relationships with colleagues, family, and friends. This is why we need to dream.'

'Twenty years ago, Susie Ray left London for a small town by the sea in south-west England. In her studio, you see empty frames on the walls and photos of her two daughters. Susie is a pioneer in the copyist art movement. She can recreate the beauty of a 20th-century impressionist painting or a 16th-century Caravaggio portrait. But she doesn't keep her own work. 'As soon as I finish them, they go,' she says. Susie is very popular. In her 30 years as a copyist artist, she has painted works by famous artists like Renoir, Monet, and Van Gogh. Her copies are so good that art experts think they are originals. While the originals are worth millions, her copies sell for a few hundred to £12,000, depending on the time she spends on them. Susie doesn't name most of her clients, but they include galleries and private collectors. Some collectors love art, but others want to show off. One celebrity likes to brag about his 'Van Gogh' painting, which is actually a 'Susie Ray Van Gogh'. 'Many famous people pretend my copies are originals,' she says. 'That's their choice.' Some collectors keep the original in a bank and display Susie's copy at home. Susie is honest about her work. She makes her copies look as real as possible and signs her name on the back. Pretending a copy is real is illegal, and she avoids that. People who make fake art often get into trouble. Susie isn't rich and has had hard times, but her life is more stable now. She doesn't want to risk her reputation. Susie wasn't always a copyist. After her art degree, she worked as an illustrator for a botanical garden. She earned very little, but it was good practice for her current work and gave her a love for plants. She had to be very precise in her drawings. She has no regrets but is glad she found something better financially. When young artists ask for advice, Susie tells them to learn to draw accurately. She has studied a lot to do her work. She can draw plants, make perfect copies of 15th-century art, and reproduce 20th-century abstract art. Now, she focuses on French impressionists like Manet, Cezanne, and Degas. Susie says people think modern art is easy, but it's not. Impressionists painted quickly but carefully, and that mix is hard to do well. It's surprising that Susie doesn't create her own art. Isn't art about self-expression? Could a Susie Ray original be worth more than a copy? She says her work is the result of years of training, and she earns well from it. She has tried her own art, like oil paintings of fishing nets, but they looked like photos. Susie is a perfectionist.'

During her racing days, nothing was more important to Ellen MacArthur than the sea, except maybe being the fastest on it. She loved the sea since she was a child. She felt a special connection with the boats that took her around the world. They worked together as one. When she was back on land, everyday life seemed unimportant, and she quickly wanted to return to the ocean, challenging herself against nature, even in dangerous places. After she came second in the Vendée Globe, a non-stop, solo round-the-world race, she showed me her boat, Kingfisher. It was her home and work space for 94 days. She talked about how carefully she planned everything, even counting how many rolls of kitchen paper she needed. Preparation was key, she said. She proudly showed her supplies of freeze-dried food, a small gas stove, and medical necessities. Her boat was her world, and she took care of it because her life depended on it.
Now, Ellen sees the world like a boat: small, beautiful, and fragile, with limited resources. Her perspective changed during a trip to South Georgia, a remote island in the South Atlantic, where she helped with a bird survey. Seeing abandoned whaling stations made her think. 'It seemed like we just took what we wanted and moved on. That’s what we do.' When I visit Ellen’s office, she finishes a conference call and explains why we must act now to save the planet. 'No one is making more coal, oil, or gas. They are precious and limited. We need to find a way not to use them up.' At first, her message was to use less, but now she talks about re-using, like reusable industrial carpet tiles. For the last three years, she has visited factories, mines, and power stations, talking to governments and businesses about our dependence on non-renewable resources. 'I will never be an expert,' she says. 'But I love learning. [The current situation] became something I couldn’t ignore. Sailing seemed selfish in comparison. This is different. It’s about finding how my voice can help. It really matters.'
She also started the Ellen MacArthur Foundation, a charity that works with businesses and education to help young people think about a sustainable future. 'I do miss the adventure of being at sea,' she says. 'It is a big part of who I am. You feel connected to everything around you. You don’t have time to feel lonely. You focus on the record, on practical things, on survival. [My new] message is not as simple as saying: “I’m going to be the fastest person around the world.” I may have been the fastest, but this is more important than anything I’ve done before.'

Jordan Romero is 13 years old and wants to be the youngest person to climb Mount Everest. If he does it, he could become very famous. Many young people spend a lot of time on computers and video games, so Jordan hopes to inspire them to go outside and try new things. Jordan's team includes his father, Paul, and his mother, Karen. They call themselves 'Team Romero.' Climbing Everest is just one of their goals. If Jordan climbs Everest and Vinson Massif in Antarctica, he will be the youngest person to climb the Seven Summits, the highest mountains on each continent. Not many people do this before they are thirty. Jordan has already climbed five of these mountains and might finish before he turns 20.
Some experienced Everest climbers think it is not a good idea for a 13-year-old to climb the mountain. They agree that a young person might be strong enough, but they worry if a teenager is emotionally ready. They also think a young person might not have enough experience to make good decisions while climbing. The Romeros know about these opinions. Paul says, 'I know people criticize us, but I can't focus on that. We have a lot to do. Karen and I think about the risks, but we believe our experience will help. Watching Jordan grow gives me confidence. He is becoming strong and mature.'
I also wonder why Jordan wants to do this. Is it because his father loves adventure? Paul says, 'This is not about me becoming famous because of my son. At first, Jordan talked about doing this later, but we thought: why not now? We talk to him often to make sure he still wants to do it.' When I ask Jordan what he enjoys about the challenge, he says, 'I just focus on achieving my goal.'
In the past, not many people cared about being the youngest or fastest to climb a mountain or sail an ocean. Now, every adventure is shared online, and every climb becomes a record challenge. This gives Jordan a problem. People might say that focusing on records takes away the fun, but if Jordan wants to inspire others, he has to share his story. This means blogging, taking photos, and giving interviews. He needs to do something amazing, like climbing Everest. Paul says, 'If Jordan decides he wants to stop climbing and play basketball instead, we will stop this project and go to the gym.'

'When you see a teenager with an MP3 player, it’s likely they are not listening to classical music. Most people can name many pop groups, but if you ask my friends about Brahms, they probably won’t know who he is. I have just started a music degree, but my classmates don’t know much about classical music either. If you don’t know who wrote the music, you probably don’t have any of their recordings. The numbers are not good for classical music fans. Only 3% of concert tickets sold last year were for classical music, and the average classical album sells only 300 copies. I find that hard to believe. So, why is there less interest in classical music, which has been around for centuries? Older people blame TV and video games, but I don’t think that’s the reason. The truth is, classical music doesn’t attract most people, especially teenagers, who buy the most music and concert tickets. I know some teenagers who go to classical concerts, but they are few. Even though I play in an orchestra, I’m not a big classical music fan. I like many styles, but I don’t listen to much classical music. So why don’t teenagers like classical music? First, the pace and rhythm of classical music, with its many mood changes, are difficult for us. We like to talk fast, play fast, and think fast. Experts say we can only focus for about three minutes, which is too short for most classical pieces but perfect for a pop song. Pop music is simple and easy to listen to, while classical music needs time and focus. Pop music topics are more interesting to us than long classical pieces without words. The way we listen to music has changed too. In the past, families played music together at home, and playing an instrument was important. The only other way to hear music was at a concert. Now, you can find any music online, but we rarely listen to classical music. When was the last time you heard classical music in a shop? One of my teachers says more people are going to classical concerts now, but I bet not many are teenagers. In my orchestra, we play classical music in many places, but I mostly see older people in the audience. I don’t know why more people like classical concerts as they get older, but I know that if your parents like something, you might avoid it. Some say schools are to blame for teenagers not liking classical music, but many kids are excited to play in their school orchestra. They come early to practice and stay late to rehearse. They like classical music when they play it, but it’s not their first choice to listen to. When we want to relax, we choose pop music.'

Bonnie Wyndham got out of her mother’s car and looked at Almonside School. "I’ll make you sorry I’ve come here," she said to the school, smiling. Her mother was getting out of the other side of the car and didn’t hear her, but Bonnie didn’t mind. Her mother knew how she felt. Mrs. Wyndham looked around. Almonside was a strange school, with buildings hidden among the trees on a hillside; it was confusing at first. Then she saw the signs: Science block, gymnasium, riding centre… "Riding centre," said Bonnie, suddenly interested. "Headmaster’s study," said her mother. "This way." Bonnie followed her mother along a wide path between the trees. "I wish you’d walk beside me instead of following me like a dog," said Mrs. Wyndham tiredly, but she didn’t expect Bonnie to change. A few minutes later, her mother was talking to Bonnie’s new headmaster in his office, while Bonnie waited outside. Suddenly, Bonnie stood up. "Why should I just sit here?" she thought. "I’ll be thrown out soon anyway," she thought to herself, "so why not get it over with?" She left the building and went to the riding centre, following the sign. There was an old building for the horses and a large place for indoor riding. Bonnie looked around, but no one was there. She approached the horses with respect. The horses were well cared for, she could see that. Almost every stall had a horse, and she looked at each one carefully. "I know what they’re doing here," she told a small pony, touching its nose. The next horse surprised her. "Aren’t you the best of the lot!" she said. He was brown with a bit of white. He looked lively, but Bonnie liked that. "I feel like we’ve met before," said Bonnie, stroking his neck. "In my dreams, I was riding you to win a big competition…" His name was Maverick. Suddenly, she wanted to ride him. "I wonder where I can find a bridle and a saddle for you." The room with the riding equipment was unlocked, which made Bonnie happy. She was so focused on putting a saddle on Maverick that she forgot about her mother and the headmaster. When she sat on the big horse outside, she felt like a queen. Her nickname at her old school was Queen Bee, and she laughed as she remembered it. "You’re the best horse I’ve ever ridden, Maverick," she said, "and I mean it, because I know about horses, even if I don’t know about anything else." She made him walk, then trot. "If I stay here, I think you and I could be great friends," she said. She rode around the paddock. The movement was exciting, and the breeze made her cheeks glow. She could tell Maverick trusted her, and she felt sure he would jump well.

Cody Simpson is a 15-year-old Australian who has become famous for his music. He is known for being quietly confident. Cody started playing the guitar at six and began writing songs at seven. He loved swimming and surfing, and these activities were very important to him. When he was 13, he posted some videos online of himself singing at a school concert. People loved the videos and wanted more, so Cody shared more videos from home. The response was amazing.
Cody was also a talented swimmer and trained with top coaches. But when record labels showed interest in his music, he had to make a big decision: stay in Australia to swim or move to the US to pursue music. Cody chose music, even though it was a difficult choice at such a young age. He had to tell his swimming coach and friends that he was moving to the US. It was a surprise to many because Cody is a quiet person. He believes it's important to stay humble in the music industry.
Cody moved to the US with his family, leaving one dream to follow another. His family supports him but stays out of the spotlight. Cody thinks it's important to have good people around to keep him grounded. Sometimes, he worries about how his decision affects his younger brother and sister, especially his eight-year-old brother who travels and studies on the road. But his family reassures him that they support him.
Cody believes success comes from taking opportunities, even if they are scary. He is amazed by how quickly everything happened and feels lucky to visit new countries and perform for many fans. He knows this success might not last forever, but he is grateful for the experience.

'I jumped out of bed, lifted a corner of the bedroom curtain, and looked at the river. A new crack in the ice shone in the morning sun. I shaded my eyes and looked upstream at the wall of sandbags. They were there to protect the buildings from flooding as the river ice melted. My back still hurt from lifting them into place. Last week, I worked with most of the town’s adults for long hours, showing I could do it. But my grandfather didn’t notice much. With one hand still on the curtain, I looked at the half-mile of steaming black water from the factory in Milltown. There was fragile ice on both sides, and solid ice downstream. As I took off my pyjamas and reached for my kayaking wetsuit, I saw a boy on the far side of the river. I didn’t know him. I frowned. He was trying to balance on an ice shelf near the warm water from the factory. I zipped up my wetsuit and reached for my kayaking jacket. I checked the pocket for the lucky chain I keep there – a silver chain my famous grandfather brought back from South America. Better than having a famous grandfather is having this chain, which only he, my mom, and I know about. Plus, I have the diary he kept on that journey. I keep it under my pillow and read it before I sleep. I patted the chain again and went to the kitchen. ‘Morning, Rex.’ Mom smiled at me as I grabbed a banana. ‘You’re up early for a Saturday. I’ll make brunch after your training. Be careful.’ ‘Thanks, Mom.’ I walked down the hallway and almost bumped into Grandpa. ‘Can’t you watch where you’re going?’ he shouted. ‘Where are you going?’ ‘Sorry, Grandpa. I’m going kayaking.’ As if my wetsuit didn’t make that clear. As if he didn’t see me in my kayak every morning. Grandpa is Grandpa, and I try to ignore it when he gets angry, but it’s getting harder. ‘What’s the point of training? You didn’t win the competition,’ he said. For a moment, his words hurt. But I took a deep breath and counted to three. He crossed the hall and slammed the bathroom door. Mom appeared with a kind smile. ‘Don’t mind him. He’s…’ ‘…not himself right now,’ I finished for her. I didn’t say he’d always been like that. But, like Mom, I try to be patient with him. When I was a child, he was my hero – from the time he showed me photos of him in National Geographic. Those old photos still hang on his bedroom wall, above his dusty medals and trophies. But I don’t go into his room anymore. I have my own growing collection of trophies to look at and, maybe soon, my own face in National Geographic. And yet, a part of me still wants to stay close to him, this grumpy old man. Mom smiled. ‘At least he’s coming out of his room more. Have a good session, Rex. I admire your determination, even on cold days!’ I smiled back as I peeled my banana. ‘It’ll be warmer in South America,’ I said. ‘If I find sponsors for my expedition.’ She laughed and went back to the kitchen. I ate my banana and went downstairs. I hurried to the boathouse.'

Mum grabbed Jess's arm. "Come with me," she said. Jess followed her to the study. On the table, leaning against the wall, was an unfinished painting by Grandpa. It was different from his other works. "Do you know anything about this?" Mum asked. Jess shook her head. "I've never seen it before. I didn't know he was working on anything." Jess looked at the picture. It showed a river, but not one she knew. It might not even be a real river, just a fantasy one. The picture was strange and beautiful in a mysterious way. The riverbank was barely visible, and the eye was drawn to the pale waters leading to a hidden sea. There were no animals, birds, or people, and it felt right that way. It seemed like there was no place for living things in this distant scene. Yet, Jess was fascinated, thinking of autumn after a long summer. Mum spoke again. "It has a name." Her voice sounded too casual, hiding her excitement. Jess understood why. Grandpa never named his pictures. He just painted them and let others interpret them. Mum turned the picture over and showed Jess the words Grandpa had written. Jess read them aloud. "River Boy." The words felt important to her, but she didn't know why. There was another mystery. She looked at Mum. "There is no boy." "Exactly. Strange, isn't it? Maybe he's going to add the boy later. I asked him about it." "Mum! You should have known better." "I know, but I couldn't help it. It's such an unusual picture, especially with a name. You can guess his response." Jess didn't need to guess. She knew what Grandpa would have said. "He told you it's not up to the artist to explain a painting because each picture has its own life and language, like a poem. We either understand it or we don't. And he said painting is hard enough without explaining it to everyone." "Ignoramus, he said." "… every ignoramus what it means. If artists had to explain their pictures to everyone, they'd never get any work done. And he said …" Mum interrupted, laughing. "Something like that. Anyway, I hoped you might know something about this painting since you seem to inspire him." "Inspire?" "Someone who gives an artist ideas." She knew what it meant. Grandpa often used the word when she watched him paint. He'd say the muse wasn't kind to him today or he needed to be nice to the muse for a difficult part. He never suggested the muse was her. She thought it was a goddess, not a person. It was hard to imagine anyone, even a goddess, influencing someone as stubborn as Grandpa. "He doesn't need me to inspire him," she said. "He's been painting all his life."

'When I woke up this morning, I didn't plan to cut a hole in my bedroom carpet. I'm not saying it was an accident, but it could have been. For example, if I had tripped over the bed with Dad's knife in my hand, the blade might have cut the carpet by itself. I'm not saying that happened, just that it could have. I didn't mean to damage the carpet. I didn't wake up thinking, 'Today I will cut a hole in my carpet.' It just seemed like a good idea at the time. Later, you wonder why you thought that, but it's too late. This happens to me a lot. I'm unlucky that way. I was actually trying to fit my corner cabinet into a corner. Gran gave me the cabinet when she moved to a flat. It's really cute! Very small, painted white, with pink and blue flowers, and tiny glass doors. Gran used to keep china ornaments in it. I keep my collection of shells and fossils there. Gran knew I always loved her cabinet. I was so excited when she gave it to me! But it's a corner cabinet, shaped like a triangle. It has to stand in a corner. I have only two corners in my bedroom because it's the smallest room in the house, shaped like a wedge of cheese. The big front bedroom is Mum and Dad's; the one at the back is my sister Angela's; the little one over the garage is my brother Tom's; and the tiny one is mine. Mum says when Angela goes to University, Tom can have her room and I can have his. And when Tom goes to University, I can choose. But Angela is only fifteen, so I'll be in my small room for years. I don't mind; I like my little bedroom. It's cosy, like a nest. I love the sloping roof and the window at floor level. The only problem is the lack of corners! My bed is in one, and my wardrobe in the other. I tried fitting Gran's cabinet between the roof and the floor, but it was a bit too tall. If I could just cut a couple of centimetres off the bottom... Then I thought, if I can't cut the cabinet, how about cutting a hole in the carpet? It seemed like the obvious solution. What Dad calls lateral thinking. I thought he would be pleased. He always tells us to 'think outside the box'. And that's what I was doing!'

The novel 'The Borrowers' is about a family of tiny people who live hidden in the walls and floors of a house. They secretly take things from normal-sized people to survive. When I was asked to direct a TV version of the novel, I knew it would be hard to meet people's expectations. Fans of the book have strong ideas about how everything should look. I used the original drawings from the book a lot because I didn't want people to say I got it wrong. The author wanted the series to show the Borrowers' view, not a human one, which made filming more complex. The most important thing was getting the size right. The Borrowers are ten times smaller than humans, so if we filmed them walking across a room or going on a borrowing mission, we had to be 10 times further away than usual. When filming the human surroundings, the crew had to crawl on the ground and film from no higher than 15 centimeters to get the Borrowers' view. They wore out many pairs of jeans! We never raised the cameras above their height except for aerial shots. One big challenge was getting the shadows right when combining images of tiny Borrowers with normal-sized backgrounds. We created a special technique for this. After the series was shown, the famous US film director George Lucas called to ask how I did it. The only permanent set we built was the Borrowers' home under the floorboards, filled with giant objects to make the actors look small. It was wonderfully surreal. When I asked them to carry things like a giant pair of scissors, they really got into it. I remember the coins - they were bigger than dinner plates and hard to lift. We often had to stop filming because they made the crew laugh so much. In the story, there’s a scene where the Borrowers are swept down a drain. To film this, actors had to be swept down a tunnel with hoses and said it was so scary, they didn’t have to act. One important thing for me, which other directors struggled with, was getting the costumes right. I had them made from heavy canvas so they stuck out like dolls’ clothes. This made it hard for the lead actress to bend in her costume. She couldn’t sit during breaks and couldn’t take the dress off because she was sewn into it every morning. The lead actor's trousers were made from a rug because normal material would look too smooth. Unfortunately, the weather was really hot during filming. I don’t think they thanked me for my attention to detail with those costumes! Most of the action away from the Borrowers’ home was shot with actors separated from their surroundings. We filmed them in front of a blue screen on an empty set. It was hard for them to react to things that weren't there. I had to draw pictures of every scene to show how each one should look – I did 2,000 of them by the end. They weren’t accurate, but they worked well enough. The budget didn’t allow time in special effects studios during the day, so I worked nights for three months. We had to work hard and fast – I once shot a whole scene before realizing there was no film in the camera. But it all came together in the end, and I think the series was pretty successful in showing the magic of the books.

Mom stops the car at the corner of my new school, Palm Grove High School. She looks around nervously, checking for journalists who aren't there. Let's see how long it takes before the craziness starts. It always does. The fake smiles, the wannabe friends, the "can-you-get-me-free-tickets-to-one-of-your-dad’s-concerts?" 'Everything’s going to be fine,' I tell her. She kisses her fingertip and touches my cheek before I get out of the car. Then she drives away, leaving me alone with this new school and new situation. But this is what I wanted. To leave my old life on the road and with tour tutors. So while the rest of the band is renting here during the recording, we’re staying for good. I wanted to come to this school because I want to meet real kids. Like a kid with a mom who works in an office or a dad who cuts grass. That would be so cool. So normal. I walk into the school’s main office. 'Hi, I need my schedule please,' I tell the school secretary. 'Name?' She looks as friendly as an ice bucket. 'Desert McGraw.' 'Desirée?' she asks, leaning closer. 'Desert,' I repeat. The secretary seems confused. 'Oh,' she says and types 'McGraw' on her keyboard. That’s one good thing. Few people recognize my last name because my dad only uses his stage name. 'What grade?' 'Eleventh.' 'One second, it’s printing,' the secretary says. Then she hands me the paper. English Literature, first period. Cool, I can handle that. English has always been my favorite subject. I’ll be late, though. English is in Room 214, second floor. I studied the map the night before, so I wouldn’t look lost. When I get to the door, I hear the teacher already calling names. 'Aurelio Gonzalez.' 'Here.' She continues while I slip in quietly and sit at the last desk in the second row. The girl next to me smiles. Her eyes look at my normal outfit – jeans and a T-shirt. Ha! Nobody will suspect me now! 'Nice shoes,' she whispers. I look down at my expensive shoes with tan embroidered flowers. Oh no, I knew I shouldn’t have worn these. Dead giveaway. 'Thanks,' I say. The teacher pauses. 'Desert... McGraw?' she says slowly. 'Here.' The teacher smiles and introduces herself as Ms. Smigla. She talks a lot and gives us our course outlines. After we review them and she tells us about the books we need to read this year, she actually gives us time to talk! All teachers should do this. 'So why’d you move here?' my new friend asks. I have lots of choices here. Do I say it’s because I wanted a normal life away from cameras and reporters? Or the real reason, according to Dad? 'We need a change, Desert,' he said, 'and this is the perfect place to record the new album. Energy, color, culture... just what our last album needed.' Personally, I think he just wants to relax on the beach. Why else would they pick South Beach Sounds, a studio near the sand? 'My dad had to relocate,' I tell her. Yes, lies work better. 'What does he do?' she asks. Oh, whatever. Everyone will find out eventually. But at least I’ll have some time to pretend to be normal until they do. 'He’s an artist,' I say, playing with the zipper on my backpack. 'Cool. I’m Becca, by the way.' And she doesn’t seem to care. Excellent.

'Today, the average American teenage girl is expected to do many things. She should be the Student Council president, have a part-time job, volunteer, and do well in all these areas. This is what being an American teenager is like now. Teenage boys and girls can't just go to school and be average. Being average is not enough anymore. If you don't have big goals, people might think you are lazy. Many adults forget how much pressure teenagers have today. We have lots of homework, tests, activities after school, jobs, chores, and responsibilities at home. We also try to have a social life,’ says teenager Kristen Loose. Even though these pressures are normal for teenagers today, negative stereotypes about them still exist. People often think teenagers are lazy, disrespectful, rebellious, loud, reckless, and self-centered. While some teenagers might be like this, it is not fair to say all of them are. ‘Many people think we spend most of our time watching TV or using our phones,’ Loose says. Loose thinks this is not true. She keeps her phone close, but not just for fun. It helps her and others in their daily lives. Students today are expected to have quick access to information and be reachable all the time, which can look like a phone addiction. With smartphones, tablets, and social media, students can do their work anywhere. They can even listen to language lessons while going to school. Schoolwork and activities now need attention all day, adding to the stress of busy teens. Many teenagers start their day at 6 a.m. or 7 a.m. and finish after midnight. Their day is full of school, activities, family duties, and homework. They often get less than the nine hours of sleep they need. The US National Sleep Foundation found that only about 20 percent of teens get enough sleep. Also, 28 percent of teens said they fall asleep in school at least once a week because they are so tired. Teenager Lindamarie Olsen says she has about 18 hours of free time each week. With 168 hours in a week, 18 hours is not much. Olsen does not waste this time on social media or TV. She spends a lot of it volunteering. ‘People think teenagers only care about themselves and their own interests,’ Olsen says. But she loves volunteering and making a positive impact in her school and community. In 20 years, we don't know what people will think about teenagers, but they will still be proving stereotypes wrong and making the world better. There will be a new generation of students who will change the world, even before they finish school.'

The teenage members of the Earth to Sky Calculus Club live in and around Bishop, a mountain town in the US, near the Sierra Nevada mountains. Over the last few years, this group has launched over fifty balloons to the edge of space, about 35 km above the Earth. This is a science project with a twist: it’s part astronomy experiment, part adventure, which attracts teenagers. I join them one weekend in late spring. They are about to release a high-altitude balloon to record shooting stars. Shooting stars happen when a rock or metal piece enters the Earth's atmosphere, creating a light trail. As it gets dark, the teenagers attach a soft insulated $5 lunch box to the balloon. Inside is a camera, an instrument to measure altitude, and a thermometer. Two GPS trackers are on the outside to help find it later. A gas tank, donated by someone from a nearby state, inflates the balloon, which grows to the size of a small car. An older boy made a seven-hour trip to get it. ‘I didn’t really mind,’ he says. For kids in this club, that’s normal. Finally, it's time for lift-off. ‘Five, four, three, two, one,’ they chant, and the balloon rises. Some run and track it with flashlights, lighting up the balloon in the dark sky. There is quiet and a sense of wonder. Then the balloon disappears into the night. After the launch, most students go home, but a few stay to watch the shooting stars. They lie on blankets and look at the clear sky, just four hours from Los Angeles, a busy city of about 4 million people. I see a boy get into a sleeping bag and fall asleep. ‘We're the only ones talking,’ says one girl quietly. ‘I know,’ whispers another. A meteor crosses the sky. As the balloon rises, the air pressure drops, and the balloon expands until it pops. A parachute helps the lunch box land safely. The students will find it the next day using the GPS trackers. Getting it back isn’t easy, but that’s part of the fun. There is little inhabited land around Bishop, so the lunch box usually lands in remote areas. ‘To me, recoveries are a big part of the program,’ said the group’s leader, who notes they've lost only two lunch boxes in 53 launches. ‘Part of the journey is getting to know this landscape in a way you normally wouldn’t.’ This time, the lunch box landed 84 km west of Bishop. To get it, the team had to drive south of the Sierra and then up the western side. They had to decide whether to drive or walk, as it could be dangerous if the lunch box was on a high peak or a tall tree. ‘These students are native to the Eastern Sierra,’ their leader says. ‘What seems wild to some is normal to others.’ It took them 11 hours to find the lunch box. It was in a canyon, on a flat rock, in a waterfall. The camera didn’t record any shooting stars. It’s a bit disappointing, but it’s a chance to discuss atmospheric waves and how they work above mountains. And it’s another adventure story to share.

Chloe Morgan admits that science, especially Palaeontology, didn't interest her much until she was fifteen. It happened by accident. Her younger brother was interested in dinosaurs, a common phase for children, which she hadn't gone through. She helped him with a science project and found an article about new discoveries in the field. It amazed her, and she knew she wanted to study it. Palaeontology was not a common career choice for young people then. Chloe remembers meeting her first professional palaeontologist, Matt Cornelius, who was already famous. She was nervous, but he was patient and willing to listen, which made her feel comfortable.
Chloe talks about how movies and TV shows portray palaeontologists. Films like Jurassic Park have increased interest in dinosaurs but not necessarily in Palaeontology. She feels that palaeontologists are often shown as either eccentric geniuses or geeky losers, which is not accurate. Her job is varied; she digs up dinosaur bones, works in labs, and writes for scientific publications. She also communicates scientific findings to the public, which she takes seriously. She wants to clear up misunderstandings about science and reach out to young people to get them interested in the natural world.
Chloe worked on the TV documentary Walking with Dinosaurs. She advised the makers to ensure the dinosaurs were accurate. The show attracted audiences of all ages because it showed dinosaurs in a new way, different from movies like Jurassic Park. Chloe believes dinosaurs fascinate us because they appeal to our sense of exploration and discovery. They remind us that there is still more to learn about our world, and Palaeontology is like time travel.

"I will say this once: when you travel by car with your family, even if you are six years old, you know you are not 'there yet,' even if you keep asking 'Are we there yet?' The truth is, when you arrive, it becomes 'here,' not 'there.' So, if you think you might be 'there,' you should ask 'Are we here yet?' Parents probably want to be 'there' more than kids do, because they hear this question many times during long car trips. What are we kids complaining about? Think about it. Wouldn't you rather relax in the back seat, with nothing to do? You can watch DVDs, listen to music, or do puzzles, while the scenery passes by outside the window. In the front seat, mum or dad is there to give out juice boxes and cookies, change the radio station, and keep everything running smoothly. Are we there yet? I hope not. That is, until someone in the car does something annoying – like my younger brother, Tim, putting his foot on my side of the seat. He can't do that! So I put my foot on his side. Then he puts his other foot, and then a hand, and soon he is in my space and we start fighting. The driver and co-pilot separate us and tell Tim to stay in his seat. This calms things down for a while. The beautiful scenery continues to pass by. Later, I try to read, but I feel a breeze on my arm. The window is not open, so where is it coming from? Tim is blowing on me from his seat. He is not touching me, so he thinks he is not doing anything wrong. The anger grows. Tim gets told off, and there is more swerving. Then things calm down again – for now. Over the years, Dad has found ways to deal with us in the back seat. For example, when we ask 'Are we there yet?' he often says, 'Yes. We are here. Get out of the car.' 'But Dad, we are still on the highway, going 70 miles an hour.' 'Oh, maybe we are not there yet.' This keeps us quiet for a while. You know you are finally 'there' when the adults get out of the car and move far away from the kids who have bothered them for hours. So remember: if mum and dad are still close enough to answer your question, then the answer is: no, you are not there yet."

John and Zuzi Morgan have opened a café in Oxford, UK, where people can enjoy coffee, cake, and play board games. They hope people will love the experience and come back. Zuzi says they started the café because everyone is busy with phones and gadgets, and they wanted to bring people together without screens. The games in their café are called 'Eurogames', which have gentle themes like farming. The first Eurogame was The Settlers of Catan, where players build settlements and trade resources. This game keeps everyone involved and was followed by 'co-operative' games where players win or lose as a team, encouraging more social interaction. Pandemic is a Eurogame where players solve global problems together. It was created by Matt Leacock, who was inspired by a game called Lord of the Rings. Leacock loved board games since he was a child, even though he often found them disappointing. With his uncle, he tried to make better games. Pandemic was very successful and its next version included storytelling, character development, and changing rules. Video games have helped the success of board games because they made playing games normal. Ben Hogg, from a games company, says everyone with a smartphone plays games now. Video games used to be social in arcades or with friends at home, but now they are mostly online. Some people miss playing games with others in person. John and Zuzi's café shows that board games are more than just fun; they are a way to connect with others in real life, and this trend is growing.

Jamie Scott has written and produced some of the biggest UK hits in recent years. His story shows why endurance and persistence are important in the music business, even if your career starts with many challenges. Jamie says his mother was a great singer and she helped him start playing the guitar. At home, he only listened to a local radio station for middle-aged people, which influenced him as he grew up. He says he was 12 before he heard a modern song. Around that time, he had to choose between tennis, which he played at a national level, and music. He spent his lunchtimes in the school music room playing the piano. He says, ‘With tennis, I was at a high level, but it was not what I wanted to do for the rest of my life. It was too much hard work.’ At 17, he left school to try to become a performer. He was in a duo with a friend who was a good guitarist but not as interested in a music career. Jamie told his parents that he wanted to write songs and play music. His dad gave him 18 months to succeed, or he would have to get a job. After some close calls with record labels, he was signed to a music publisher at 19 because of one song. However, record labels wanted him as a solo artist, so he had to leave his friend. In the end, he became successful behind the scenes rather than on stage. After a tough time with a UK record label, he asked to leave and joined another label to release a new album. Fame and fortune did not come. He says, ‘In my artist career, I was often in the wrong place at the wrong time, but as a writer, I was in the right place at the right time.’ Writing for others is where he found success. He says, ‘I’d like to think I am one of the main writers in the UK that labels send new artists to.’ This helps start their careers. Sometimes he explains to artists that writing with the charts in mind is okay. He asks, ‘Don’t you want 10 million people streaming your music next month?’ He believes they should write songs that are amazing and likely to sell well. It is refreshing to hear someone speak honestly about wanting to write number-one hits. Jamie is not arrogant; he just knows he wants to write hits and has the talent to do it. He focuses on writing the best music. ‘That’s the goal when I go into the studio,’ he says. ‘We need to write the best music of next year. It’s not just about what’s cool. We want to write classic modern pop songs.’

Tony Connor is a new kind of celebrity. He is very famous online, but people who don't watch online videos of bike stunts might not know him. Tony is a 'street trials cyclist'. This means he jumps from one difficult place, like a roof or a wall, to another. These stunts are filmed and shared online.
I met Tony at a BMX park on a Saturday morning. The local boys knew him well, and even older people came to say he is 'an absolute legend'. After seeing his skills, I agreed. I was surprised by his bravery and creativity. Before each stunt, Tony explained what he wanted to do, and I wasn't always sure he could do it. But he did, and when I praised him, he didn't seem very interested. Even though he is famous online, Tony says he doesn't like being a celebrity. He finds it hard to talk to fans and prefers doing stunts instead of talking about them.
Tony's fame comes from social media and new camera technology. This technology helps him make a living. He says, 'Sometimes I feel everyone is looking at a screen, and I don't always like that.' But he is not complaining. His videos help him earn money from what used to be just a hobby.
I have learned from interviewing top athletes that two things are important to become great: energy and the ability to handle disappointment. These are more important than talent. In risky sports, you need mental strength. Even in the park, Tony fell a few times but kept trying until he succeeded.
Not everyone thinks Tony is a hero. Some say he takes too many risks. Tony says these people don't understand the sport. They don't know he gets expert advice to make the stunts safer. Tony is careful about risks. He says, 'Some people never get scared, but they shouldn't do these sports. It's good to know the dangers. I feel fear but find a way to overcome it. I plan and prepare a lot. Sometimes I ride around to get ready before a new stunt. I know I must not lose my nerve before I jump. If I fully commit, I'm fine.'

'In recent years, universities in the UK and around the world have started to encourage new students to get involved with research early in their studies. This is because research is not just for famous scholars or scientists. It is a natural way to build knowledge and skills. Research skills are useful not only in your studies but also in jobs, as they help you think about the world and your work. As a student, you contribute to knowledge. You do not just learn and repeat it; you create it. Creating knowledge means asking questions like Why? How? When? What does this mean? What if this were different? These questions are part of what we call research. Research can be very complex and world-changing, done by highly trained people. But it can also be simple, like asking questions about everyday things. Most students have done some research before, like for school projects or at work. You have also used research skills when planning a holiday, fixing things at home, or shopping online. In college, you are expected to have an enquiring mind, find problems and questions, explore information, and create your own ideas. Some students may find this hard because, in some cultures, knowledge is seen as something you get from teachers and books without questioning. But in the UK, US, and many other places, it is important to question knowledge and authority. This can be challenging, but critical thinking is very important in research. We need to not just repeat what we read but think about it, test it, and see if it is logical and supported by evidence. We should not just accept information without questioning it.'

Cities have always been places of learning and creativity. In the 18th century, people in London met in coffee houses to talk about science and politics. In modern Paris, artists like Pablo Picasso discussed art in cafés. However, living in a city is not always easy. Those same London coffee houses also spread diseases like cholera, and Picasso eventually moved to the countryside. Cities are full of creativity, but they can also be stressful and unnatural.
Scientists are now studying how city life affects our brains. They have found that cities can make our thinking less sharp. One reason is the lack of nature. Studies show that hospital patients heal faster when they can see trees. Even a small view of nature can help our brains because it gives us a break from city life.
For the first time in history, most people live in cities. We are crowded into busy places with many strangers. This can affect our mental and physical health. Walking in a city requires our brains to focus on many things, like avoiding traffic and watching out for dangers. This constant attention is tiring because our brains have to decide what to focus on and what to ignore.
Natural places, on the other hand, do not need as much mental effort. This idea is called attention restoration theory, created by psychologist Stephen Kaplan. He believed that being in nature helps our brains recover. Nature captures our attention without causing stress, unlike city noises like police sirens.
Long ago, philosophers and landscape architects warned about the effects of city life and tried to bring nature into cities. Parks like Central Park in New York give people a break from city life. A well-designed park can improve brain function quickly. While people try many things to boost brain power, like energy drinks or changing office designs, simply walking in nature seems to be very effective.
Despite the mental challenges of city life, cities continue to grow. Even in the digital age, they remain centers of creativity. Research shows that the same crowded city features that tire our brains also lead to innovation. The many social interactions in cities drive creativity. Just like 18th-century London, modern cities like Cambridge, Massachusetts, are successful creative hubs.
The challenge is to reduce the mental stress of city life while keeping its benefits. As the saying goes, sometimes people get tired of nature and want to return to the city.

'Where should we look for the mind? Many people think that thinking happens only inside our heads. Today, we have advanced brain scans to show this. But I believe the study of the mind should not stop at the brain. There is a lot of evidence, from ancient times to now, that objects and tools also play a part in how we think. Archaeology shows that stone tools, jewelry, engravings, clay tokens, and writing systems have been important in human evolution and the development of the mind. So, I suggest that what is outside the head might also be part of the mind. 
It is easy to see why people think the mind and brain are the same. Most studies on the mind separate people from the objects around them. This is necessary for brain scans, but it misses the fact that much of our thinking happens outside our heads. I do not deny that the brain is important for thinking, but I believe the mind is more than just the brain. Human intelligence might extend beyond the brain into culture and the material world. This is the idea behind a new theory I developed called Material Engagement Theory (MET). MET looks at how objects become part of our thinking, like when we use clay to make numbers or a stone to make a tool. It also studies how these ways have changed over time and what that means for how we think.
Think of a blind person with a stick. Where does this person’s self begin? The stick and the person become one, showing how the mind and objects can be connected. The stick helps the blind person feel the world, and the brain treats the stick as part of the body. This shows that human intelligence can change by using new tools. My approach sees the human mind as always evolving. The 'stick' in our history, from stone tools to the internet, is a pathway for understanding the world. Humans use 'sticks' to learn and discover. This is why humans make things, and these things shape our minds. I call this metaplasticity – our minds change as they interact with the material world. MET offers a new way to understand how objects, from stone axes to smartphones, have shaped and changed our minds. Mind-changing technology sounds futuristic, but humans have used it since they first evolved.'

'Few inventions have changed the world as much as photography. This is especially true in the United States, where photography quickly became part of American culture. It was used in many areas, like science, industry, art, and entertainment. Historians say photography might be the greatest American contribution to the visual arts. Photography became very important in the US, and to understand its impact, we need to look at its beginnings in the mid-19th century. Why was photography so popular? First, because it was a mechanical process, it matched the growing interest in technology. Like steam power and railroads, photography brought the world closer, showing people new sights. Second, the camera was a tool to represent oneself, important in a country where identities were always changing. Third, the camera helped families keep a record of themselves, even if it was idealized. Finally, photographs were realistic, matching the US artists' focus on everyday life. A photograph shows what the photographer wants us to see, saying, "This, you should see!" Photographs are records of events, people, and things, showing what was in front of the camera. But they also show the photographer's point of view. We might think we understand a photograph because we recognize the subject, but its meaning is more complex. No image is shown without some information that affects how we understand it, like a caption or its place in a gallery. To understand a photograph historically, we need to know why it was made and how people first saw it. The same image can have different meanings in different places and times. Photography's importance to artists was once a secret, but now it is well-known. For decades, artists like Andy Warhol have used photographs in their work. Photographic vision is now seen as an important part of art, not separate from painting, but essential to it.'

'In 1890, William James, an American philosopher and one of the founders of modern psychology, called psychology the ‘science of mental life’. This definition is still useful today. We all have thoughts and feelings, so we have some idea of what mental life means. Psychology can be studied in animals like rats and monkeys, but it is often focused on humans. James believed human psychology includes thoughts, feelings, the physical world, and how we understand these things. This understanding is personal and comes from our own experiences. We often act like amateur psychologists when we give opinions on why people behave in certain ways, like feeling unhappy or quitting their jobs. However, people can see things differently, which can cause problems. Formal psychology tries to find the best explanations for these situations. Psychologists help us tell the difference between personal opinions and scientific facts. They study the mind and brain, but they do not fully understand how the brain works. Instead, they learn by observing behavior and making guesses about what happens inside us. Psychology is like solving a puzzle, using clues from careful observation and analysis. It aims to describe, understand, predict, and control behavior. Psychology helps in many areas, like teaching children to read, designing safer machines, and helping people express their feelings. Although people have talked about psychological questions for a long time, scientific study of psychology began about 150 years ago. Early psychologists used introspection, or looking into one's own mind, to find answers. But this method has limits. William James compared it to trying to see darkness by turning on a light. Today, psychologists prefer to base their theories on observing others' behavior rather than just their own thoughts.'

'In a storehouse in a business park in Michigan, USA, there is a place called the Museum of Failed Products. This museum shows the other side of consumer culture, where not all products succeed. Here, you can find unusual items like A Touch of Yogurt shampoo and Breakfast Cola, which were not popular and were taken off the market. The museum is owned by a company called GfK, and its owner, Carol Sherry, believes each product tells a sad story of failure for the designers and marketers. Surprisingly, the museum is a successful business. Many companies do not keep their failed products, so executives visit the museum to learn from these mistakes. The museum started by accident when Robert McMath, a former marketing man, began collecting new products in the 1960s. He wanted a 'reference library' of products, not just failures. However, he discovered that 'most products fail,' so his collection mostly includes unsuccessful items. This shows how today's culture of optimism might lead to failed products. People in meetings might not realize a product will fail, or they might invest more money to try to make it succeed. Often, no one wants to talk about what went wrong. This focus on optimism is also common in the 'self-help' field, where people believe that thinking positively will lead to success. Neuroscientist Tali Sharot found that people tend to believe things will go better than they actually might. Psychologist Gabriele Oettingen studied 'positive fantasies' and found that thinking too much about success can reduce motivation. People who imagined having a successful week at work often achieved less. Psychologist Carol Dweck says our view of failure depends on our beliefs about ability. Some people think ability is fixed, while others believe it can grow with effort. Those who see ability as fixed fear failure because it shows their limits. In contrast, those who see ability as changeable view failure as a chance to grow. Dweck compares this to weight-training: muscles grow stronger when pushed to their limits. Having a mindset that embraces growth is a happier way to live, whether or not it leads to success.'

'Everyone knows that sports teams have an advantage when they play at home. But why is that? Many people think they know the answer, but professional sports are changing quickly, and what we used to believe is now being questioned. Two main reasons are science and money. Sports scientists want to understand what helps players perform their best, and they have many ideas about home advantage. On the other hand, people who manage money in sports wonder if home advantage should matter. If players are paid well, shouldn't they play well anywhere? 
What about the fans? Would it matter if Manchester United played some home games in the Far East to reach their fans there? It would matter to British fans, who think their team needs their support. Fans often believe that when they cheer, their team scores. But they forget the times when cheering didn't lead to a goal. 
However, one thing fans believe is true. Home fans often try to influence the referee. In an experiment, referees watched a match with and without crowd noise. Those who heard the noise were less likely to call fouls against the home team. This shows that referees might avoid making decisions that upset the home crowd.
Studies show that home advantage has decreased in all major sports, but not as much as expected. For example, in the 1890s, home football teams in England won 70% of the points, compared to 60% today. Travel used to be difficult, but now players travel in comfort, and stadiums are similar. Yet, these changes don't fully explain the data.
Home advantage varies by sport. Basketball has the most home advantage, followed by football. Baseball has the least. One reason might be that baseball is more about individual players, while basketball and football require teamwork. Playing at home might boost team confidence.
Another reason could be related to players' emotions. Studies found that players' testosterone levels were higher before home games. This might be a natural urge to defend their home ground. In the Rugby World Cup, some home teams won against stronger opponents by using determination and aggression, showing home advantage. As one referee said, 'It’s the law of the jungle out there.''

"‘The more I practise, the luckier I get,’ said golfer Gary Player about 50 years ago. This saying is famous in sports and is valued by athletes and coaches. The quote's origin is debated, with many claiming it came from other golfers. Its meaning is also interesting. Player didn’t mean he was literally lucky; he meant, ‘The more I practise, the better I get.’ This idea is part of the nature-nurture debate: is talent something you are born with, or can it be developed? In sports, the focus has been more on practice than on natural talent. Psychologist Anders Ericsson is known for the idea that you can become an expert in any field with 10,000 hours of practice. This theory is popular and has inspired books like Malcolm Gladwell’s "Outliers." These books suggest that practice is the most important factor in becoming an expert. However, in his book, Epstein argues that practice alone is not enough. He points out that studies often focus only on successful people, which can be misleading. Epstein explores why some people have certain abilities and others don’t, looking at factors like environment, support, and determination. He travels around the world, from Kenya to Sweden, to find answers. In Alaska, he learns that the drive of husky dogs in sled races might be partly genetic. This suggests that determination might also have a genetic component. Epstein talks about the difference between 'hardware' (nature) and 'software' (nurture) and says both are important for elite athletes. He does not ignore the role of training or environment, suggesting that if Usain Bolt had grown up in the US, he might have become a basketball player instead of a sprinter. Epstein also discusses race and gender, asking why men and women compete separately if only practice matters. Sometimes, the simplest questions are the most important."

'A recent international report shows that many children in rich countries feel lonely and unhappy. Jay Griffiths asks: why are children today so unhappy? In her book, Kith, Griffiths explains that children spend too much time indoors, in front of screens like TVs and computers, and have lost touch with nature. She believes this is the main problem. A study interviewed children and found that many would be happier if they could play outside more. Many adults over 40 remember their childhoods fondly, talking about playing outside all day. They think this was healthier than how children live now. However, these adults are the ones who have made rules to keep their children safe indoors. Griffiths discusses how fear of danger keeps kids inside and helps the toy and gadget industry sell more products. She also talks about how some children are given medicine for being restless or are made to wear goggles for playground games. Griffiths is passionate about children having freedom, but sometimes she goes too far. She compares modern treatment of children to racism, which seems extreme. Griffiths is very romantic about children, seeing them as perfect, which might not be realistic. She believes children should have freedom to explore and take risks, saying they need small accidents to learn. But she doesn't explain how to ensure these accidents are safe. Also, not all children want to explore; some are naturally quiet and prefer staying home. Maybe the real issue is forcing all children to live the same way, whether keeping them inside or pushing them outside.'

I am a research bio-psychologist with a PhD, so I have studied a lot. I am good at solving problems in my work and life, but this is not because of my schooling. Most life problems cannot be solved with complex formulas or memorized answers from school. They need judgment, wisdom, and creativity from life experiences. For children, these experiences come from play. My recent research focuses on the value of play for children's development. All mammals, including humans, play when they are young. Those with more to learn play more. Carnivores play more than herbivores because hunting is harder to learn than grazing. Primates play more than other mammals because their lives depend more on learning than on instincts. Children, who have the most to learn, play more than any other young primates when they can. Play is how adults and mammals have always educated themselves. The most important skills for children to live happy, productive, moral lives cannot be taught in school. These skills are learned and practiced in play. They include creativity, getting along with others, cooperating, and controlling impulses and emotions. Creativity is important for economic success. We need people who can ask new questions and solve new problems, not just follow instructions or do routine calculations. If we can develop thinkers who anticipate problems, we will have a strong workforce. This requires creative thinking. A creative mind is a playful mind. Geniuses are adults who keep and build on their childlike creativity. Albert Einstein said school almost destroyed his interest in math and physics, but he regained it after leaving school. He called his work 'combinatorial play'. He developed his theory of relativity by imagining himself chasing a sunbeam. We cannot teach creativity, but we can suppress it with schooling that focuses on set questions and answers. More important than creativity is getting along with others, caring for them, and cooperating. Children are born wanting to play with others, and through play, they learn social skills, fairness, and morality. Play is voluntary, meaning players can quit. If you can't quit, it's not play. Players know they must keep others happy to continue the game. This makes play very democratic. School has become harder: breaks are shorter, homework has increased, and there is more pressure for high grades. Outside school, adult-directed sports have replaced spontaneous games. 'Play dates' with adults have replaced unsupervised neighborhood play, and adults now feel they must intervene instead of letting children solve their own problems. These changes have been gradual but significant. They are due to social factors like parents' fears, warnings from experts, less community, and the belief that children learn more from adults than from each other. Our children need more play, not more school. If we care about our children and future generations, we must change this trend. We must give childhood back to children. They need to follow their natural drives to play and explore to become strong adults ready for an unpredictable future.

In many countries, more people in their twenties are using social media to find jobs. Websites like Twitter and LinkedIn allow them to contact potential employers directly. This is similar to standing outside an office with a "hire me" sign. However, with more access, there is also a higher chance of making mistakes. For example, a young jobseeker in the US contacted a senior marketing executive on LinkedIn. The executive had many important contacts, and the jobseeker hoped they could help him get a job. But the executive was upset by his request. She refused his contact request and sent a harsh rejection note, which became very popular online. People who saw the note were shocked, and the executive might regret her tone. However, this incident might help young people think more carefully about using social media for work. It shows that social media can be risky for job seekers who do not know how to use it properly. Many young people are making mistakes. This is ironic because social media sites like Facebook and Twitter have been a big part of their social lives for years. When my generation was young, social media was a way to escape from parents and teachers. It was a place to impress and experiment, often based on fantasy. You could talk to someone online for hours and then ignore them at school. By choosing certain pictures or songs for your Facebook page, you could become a different person overnight. But when using social media for professional networking, our experience with sites like Facebook might be a problem. Using social media for work is very different, but some young people do not see the difference. We first became popular online by being bold and confident, which might be why some of us still think this is a good idea. Just because many people liked your posts on Facebook, it does not mean you can use LinkedIn to show employers you are worth hiring. We need to understand that what we learned about social networking as teenagers does not apply now. We must meet employers' standards to succeed in the job market. Employers often complain that young job seekers on professional networking sites are too familiar and seem arrogant. This makes older generations think of us as an "entitled generation." In reality, many of us are desperate to find jobs, which is why we use social media. This impression of arrogance can hurt young people's chances of getting a job, even if they have the skills and motivation to be valuable workers. So, how should you contact someone on a professional networking site? First, clearly explain who you are and what you can offer them, like doing research or helping in some way. This approach gives you a better chance of getting a positive response. Avoid sending impersonal emails, and keep your tone humble to avoid offending the recipient. Remember, social media can be a great way to make useful contacts, but it needs careful handling to avoid closing doors.

'Predicting the future of newspapers is very difficult. If you look at the numbers, newspapers seem to be in trouble. Since 2000, the number of people buying UK national newspapers has dropped by a third to a half. In the USA, only 26% of people now say newspapers are their main news source, compared to 45% in 2001. Some people think printed newspapers will disappear in 15 years. However, old media often survive. In 1835, a journalist said books and theatre were finished, but they survived. Theatre, radio, and cinema have all continued despite new media like TV and DVDs. Even vinyl records are popular again, with sales up 745% since 2008. Newspapers were once new media too. They became popular in the mid-19th century with the steam press, railway, and telegraph. People started to want regular news updates. In medieval times, people didn't expect change and only noticed big events like famine or disease. Journalism as a job started in the 19th century. Back then, people didn't need news every day or week. Newspapers have a fixed format, but online news is flexible. Online, we can choose news that interests us and get updates quickly. Mistakes can be fixed fast, and there is no limit to how much can be written. However, online news often focuses on being first and getting comments, which can cause confusion. In medieval times, news was shared in markets or taverns, mixed with rumors. We might be going back to that. Newspapers have not always explained the world well. They might disappear, or they might help us understand our chaotic world.'

'If humans were truly comfortable under the light of the moon and stars, we would enjoy walking in the dark, just like many animals that are active at night. But we are daytime creatures, with eyes made for sunlight. This is a basic part of who we are, even if we don't often think about it. This is why we have changed the night by adding light to it. We have filled the night with artificial light, similar to how we control rivers with dams. This has benefits, but also problems, known as light pollution. Light pollution happens because of poor lighting design, which lets light shine into the sky instead of focusing it on the ground. This extra light changes the natural darkness, affecting many living things, including us. It can disturb migration, reproduction, and feeding. In the past, the idea of 'light pollution' would not have made sense. Imagine walking towards London on a moonlit night around 1800. Back then, nearly a million people lived there, using candles and lanterns. Only a few houses had gas lights, and there were no streetlights. From a distance, you would smell London before seeing its faint glow. We have lit up the night as if it were empty, but it is not. Many animals are active at night.
